000179.question: where do you see yourself in 30 years

000180.question: How did you help yourself break out of the 'norm' and go into the uncharted part of the human life? You seem to have realized a special attitude towards the tried and tested very young in your life and would love to know what factors helped you be brave enough to live up to the ideology.
000180.answer: the fact that i never really fit in pushed me that way. i spent a lot of time learning music (only on instruments) at a very young age, and avoiding anything 'popular.' then sometime when i was a teenager i just snapped and said wait a minute, what's popular? more specifically, where is the real cutting edge? i was a little disappointed to realize that most of what's popular is usually actually not the cutting edge ... but i began searching for the cutting edge, whatever that should be. and i sort of tumbled into a huge search, which finally cumulated in the realization that because infinite universes do and can exist, they have to all be right. and that exploded into some heavy ideas about what this all means and why we're here. i've spent my entire life since then trying to figure out how to explain that. what makes that challenging is the fact that the only way to actually explain it is to prove that it has already been explained

000181.question: "i will have my own music and visual studio..i will also have a great band and live show" this imperative attitude is commonplace for people who achieve brilliant things. Is it something you've always had or have you taught yourself this strong self-belief? I struggle with self-esteem issues,you see
000181.answer: expressing things to a wide audience is the only way i can get my life to make sense. so it's worth a shot

000182.question: what are we
000182.answer: what you are is your own opinion, me personally im-a-person.mp4 expressing things to a wide audience is the only way i can get my life to make sense. so it's worth a shot

000183.question: In your 'movies' video did you choose the featured movies for any particular reason (maybe that you liked them?) or were they just arbitrary choices?
000183.answer: by that point, i was well into emergency "crunch time" mode, trying to finish vines as fast as humanly possible in order to make time to work on an extremely long video i was trying to get started. ideally for that vine i would have found a broad range of different movies, but instead i just grabbed them all from the same page, literally the first page i found with a lot of movie images. as a result, i think they are all 2013 movies

000184.question: "because infinite universes do and can exist, they have to all be right." please can you elaborate? I know you elaborate with your music, videos, website etc. but can you offer a little more text to describe what you mean? Why, in particular, do they 'have to all be right'?
000184.answer: i don't know.... try finding a number that doesn't add up to itself

000185.question: How would you describe your sense of humour?
000185.answer: luckily i don't have to. the fun part is doing stuff and leaving other people to figure out what the hell it is. if i had to label everything i do i wouldn't be doing this

000186.question: What are your thoughts on the popularity explosion of 'history of japan'?
000186.answer: glad i am no longer pigeon-holed as a viner. my next task will be to get out of being pigeon-holed as a history teacher

000187.question: What confuses you about the concept of favourites?
000187.answer: most things are made up of so many different elements, many of which can be so likable and/or unlikable in so many different ways. even if you could figure out whether you 'like' an entire thing, then you would have to figure out if you actually like it more or less than another thing. and then on top of that, you expect that to never change? it's a mindfuck.

000188.question: Is it true that you don't play guitar in your videos cause you don't know how to play it well?
000188.answer: i do play guitar in videos where applicable. (a good example is in crazy/raining). but all of the music is actually all done on keyboard. i don't delve into any audio recording (except for vocals). given the time constraints, and the fact that i'm working alone, an all-midi approach is so right for me in so many ways.

000726.question: You think so smart but simplistic your views on life are amazing how did you get to your level of thinking?
000726.answer: i had a scare where some of these answers were showing up randomly in google searches. so i started trying to answer questions in as few words as possible. it is tempting for me to answer questions in a billion words, but as i've grown in popularity i find that this exposes me enormously to trolls, who will pick apart anything i have said. so i have learned to drastically reduce the size of my answers, using harrison ford as a role model.

000728.question: but how do you find the right thing? just listen? but that's so hard to do when everyone around you is so loud and tries to tell you their own ideas of what the right thing is, and it's even harder when your thing doesn't exist yet
000728.answer: it can be stressful when everyone is re-enforcing the same old ideas. but the fact that you have the feeling of wanting to break away is proof of existence. photo-copy that and stamp it as proof that you are real. then just start building upon that. set up some free space where you are free to brainstorm ideas and save them. your situation sounds very familiar to me, and i would be glad to give you more tips. please get in touch if you need to, my email is on the email page

000729.question: Do you have issues with focus when working on a specific project? If so, how do you reign yourself back in when it's not very interesting at that moment to work on?
000729.answer: this is an 'angel's voice, tapping you on the shoulder and saying 'are you sure this is the right project?' so you lay around for a few hours and contemplate the question. and if you are sure it is, then that's the go ahead. if you still feel things are moving slowly, then go to a microscopic next-step approach. also perhaps you are a bit off track in this section of the project. consider tightening up or drastically simplifying that particular part of the project. that will often clear things right up, and get you right back to focusing on your original reasons for doing the whole thing in the first place. it's like a tree. you are way out on the branches. get back to the trunk, that branch ur on might not even matter

000757.question: How do you decide what key a song should be in? Do you live in a relative world where the 12 keys are basically interchangeable, except for logistical things that might set them apart, such as how they suit your vocal range or whether some number of sharps makes for easier fingerings? Or do you live in an absolute world where the keys have truly distinct harmonic identities? Curious to hear whatever you have to say about this.
000757.answer: the 2 most important factors are- vocal range, and whether or not i have recently done something similar in the exact same key. i used to get attached to the original key, but then i realized that it is a smart and professional move to find the best key for your voice before you record it.

001017.question: how do you deal with the: oh, this chord feels nice. oh, this one feels better. oh, this one is actually better than the two before. oh, this one is kinda in between, etc. whenever I'm making a song I can't help but think whether the chords I used were the best. Have you ever felt like this?
001017.answer: yes, absolutely. i will nitpick every little thing, often even how loud to play each note of the chord. there's basically 2 solutions: worry about it forever, or stop worrying about it Now. after you stop worrying about it and put out a couple (or a hundred) "really sloppy songs," you will eventually realize you are bulletproof enough to venture to worry about the chords "just the right amount." but you will never get there unless you lower your standards enough to get the machine moving. also, plot twist, if you really are as sensitive as you say you are, even your sloppiest version is actually going to be pretty great.

001021.question: hey Bill,have you got a name for that classic soul progression that goes VI-V-Im-VIIm-III-VI-V -Im? Like "just the two of us" or "if you want me to stay" (but in this case already beggining in the root), and have you ever heard any nice twists to it? Keep up the good work! Love you
001021.answer: i don't have a name for it, other than to say it's the good old "5min to set up the 4" except it's used from the perspective of the relative minor. so like, if you're in a minor key, it's when you go ahead and smack the flat7min7, to set up the b6. honestly, a pretty slick version of this which you might get a kick out of, is in the verse of 'let me love you one more time' (benson). and then there's obviously biggie's 'big poppa' which i believe is actually just isley brothers. also check out the second verse of a song called "You" by mya, on the word "grow." this one has the extra passing tone thrown in for bonus points. Also, another twist i just thought of -- a lot of songs do like a 2-5 and then another 2-5 a whole step lower -- so it actually kind of has that same effect when it hits the 2 of the second 2-5-- sounds like the b7min7. example of that would be c'est la vie by robbie neville. 'love' by musiq does another one chromatically in the verse, but the melody doesn't obey it as well as the 'mya' example. here's one that may seem subtle -- there was a mariah carey song (maybe 2006??) called 'shake it off" it's really just 3 chord hits, but it implies the same thing. t-pain 'show you how' also uses it pretty quick. also 'luv' by janet jackson uses it very expertly, with a gold-plated tritone substitution thing for the inbetween chord. basically all these are the b7min7 (to usually set up the b6) from a minor key. hope that's what you meant, i'm just taking that as the main common thread between your examples. ultimately this is a good technique, which i bet not many people know nowadays, and it is surely a great way to get chicks

001375.question: i know you work alone, I get that. but have you ever tried creating with another person? The biggest advantage I take out of this is because it is more fun, to laugh with another one. keep up the good work! love you
001375.answer: trust me, the only reason i work alone is because i have to. i spent years and years thinking you were "supposed" to collaborate, and that i was just messed up for not being able to make it work. i knew i "could" do it alone, but i thought it was frowned upon. and i knew it would certainly be more enjoyable and less lonely to work together with someone. but i very rarely found anyone i could work with, and i tried many many times to collaborate and failed miserably. i just always wanted to take it to mars way too quickly. no one would really take me seriously. while the whole time i thought i was the one being serious. finally i saw an interview with a very successful songwriter about collaboration, and he said "i actually don't collaborate well. one of the reasons i like songwriting is because it's something you can actually do all by yourself." that's when i finally stopped feeling guilty about it, and that's when the real work started. ever since then everything has been going fine, although i am still lonely

001393.question: how do dreams work?
001393.answer: you stop accepting input from your eyes, ears, etc, but your mind keeps running. so that means even the smallest tiny little bits of input (thoughts, memories, etc.) can manifest into realities. but because they are not actual sensory input from the solid outside world, they are prone to wild transformation on a moment to moment basis.

001404.question: What font do you use.. Helvetica? and why?
001404.answer: i used to worry about different fonts for everything, but that became not only a waste of time, but also distracting from a viewing standpoint. i ultimately made a decision to actually use the default font for everything. it gave me a lot of creative clarity, and greater efficiency. i learned it's better to focus on your strong points, and don't worry about things that are not your strong points. i don't make my own fonts, and i don't have access to a large font libary, so this would not be a strong point. by religiously using the default font only, i found that i could instantly put all my focus on things that are my strong points -- positioning, angles, motion, and timing.

001425.question: in some of your short music jingle videos you repeat the content twice in the video but other times you don't. is there a pattern of some kind to this?

001643.question: hey not to like tell you how to do your website, cause it's yours and people bother you about that all the time, but i just thought you'd like to know that if you embedded your videos from youtube instead of uploading them to your site they'd load faster. 001643.answer: i think they would run slower if i did that. also it is extremely important that it runs without glitches once it loads, and also to be able to have quick access to any point in the video, easy pause/unpause, etc. all those things are made extremely difficult on youtube. also, easy downloadability is something i value above all else. the ultimate viewing experience is watching it on your hard drive, in my opinion. that's why it is extremely important to me to provide that experience for people. that's what this site is for- i'm giving you all this content. for those who prefer the youtube experience, they can watch on youtube. and for the shorter ones i would recommend vine

001825.question: ok i've got first verse, chorus, second verse, second chorus. now what?
001825.answer: take a deep breath, and run through the song. the song already has a strong identity. ask the song what it needs, if anything. to do this right, you need to keep cleaering your head and running the song from the beginning, and right as you are getting to the end of the second chorus, that's when you will have the clearest idea of what needs to happen. Remember to remain open to all possibilities! including nothing. this part of songwriting is something i call "finishing" because there is really no telling what it's going to need. every song is different. i've heard so many songs that in my opinion fail at 'finishing' because they didn't take proper care to figure out what's best for that song. in other words, having a bridge when there shouldn't be a bridge. having the wrong kind of bridge. bridges are unpredictable anyway and this ties in with the 'be open to anything' strategy. this is a very sensitive part of the process, and every song needs something distinctly different, and quite possibly nothing. you will only know clearly after doing a full run through, and start paying attention about halfway through second chorus. many times your next step will be something that almost interrupts the end of the chorus to go to a different thing. other examples of things that work in some songs are: another verse with no lyrics. another chorus with no lyrics. maybe a totally different thing with no lyrics. another chorus with different lyrics. a totally different thing with lyrics. but this is a sensitive issue and every song has very distinctive needs, so you need to make sure you are doing full run throughs and really let the song decide what it needs or doesn't need.

001841.question: I'm a poet and wonder if song is the next form of my art. I have little skill in music; words are my clay, and I can sculpt them to any shape I desire...but what is the link between the beauty of words and the resplendence of music?
001841.answer: there are many different ways of doing all this, but in my experience, the music picks up a lot of the slack. most great songs look very short on paper (if you just look at the lyrics), and also look very nothing. most times when people write things that are meant to stand on their own without music, and then try to put to music, there is usually way too much content to fit in a song, and often there are many words that look good on paper but just aren't very singable. then again, this can be done many many different ways. the only way i know is to do it all at the same time. i think songwriting might be more similar to writing a script for a movie than poetry.

002187.question: Maybe a lame question (cause music can speak for itself) but is their any story behind "you're free to do whatever you want to"? I know at the end of the video it appears you wrote the song about 6 years ago.
002187.answer: i had just moved into a church. also had just broken up with my girlfriend. i had a lot of free time, and started writing a lot. i was experimenting with a writing technique which i was calling "murder your demon" which is where you deliberately say complete garbage at the top of the song for 4 bars (or anywhere in the song), and try to be as terrible as possible and get it all out of your system. if you actually aim straight at hell on purpose, it has interesting effects on what comes next. songs like fever (is what makes you sick), blind (to no avail), feel okay, 2010, i like, free to (do whatever you want to), tape deck, barf on me, the summertime, and song 41 were all written during that month (august 2010). i recorded some of them during the following weeks/months, and some of them remained unrecorded until years later. some still unrecorded (not mentioned).

002377.question: can you reveal, or have you already, which song(s) made no sense that you wrote outside the brooklyn museum?
002377.answer: let me see if i can explain this clearly... 9.17.10 was the actual writing session, actually sitting outside the brooklyn museum, with a binder (with paper). i was writing really short stupid tunes. the first one was called 'run.' the second one was called 'write me another.' 'write me another' got recorded a month later, along with many others. 'run' never got recorded. much later, in 2013 during a year-long writing sweep, both of those songs came up for evaluation/re-write/delete consideration. 'run' actually got split into 2 songs -- i basically separated the 'run' part and called that its own song (run), and then i took the 'looking glass' part and added a new ending, ('elf') which actually carries on the original narrative and explains more details about the 2010 writing session (fine morning in brooklyn, etc etc). 'write me another' also got a 2013 evaluation (which was unusual for already recorded songs, but for some reason i thought it was worth looking at) and one of the possible endings i was looking at was "i'm gonna plan my day"... but that line ended up being its own thing. another option was 'i just wrote a song and it made no sense, i'm here outside the brooklyn museum, etc etc" and that is the one i ended up going with. so, again, this actually explains more details about the original situation, despite the fact that that part was actually written years later. later still, in 2014, when i was doing 4 videos a week and 1 song every wednesday, the new version of "just wrote a song (now called brooklyn museum)" got recorded. so as a result, there are 2 recordings that start with the exact same line (i just wrote a song) one recorded in 2010 and one recorded in 2014. the 'i'm gonna plan my day' bit also got picked for a wednesday during 2014. also, the 'elf' bit got picked. it's important to remember that during 2014, i had to pick short songs way too often, because there just wasn't enough time to do anything of length, and anything short that was any good got picked earlier in the year, so by september (or whenever it was) i was only left with the worst ones (like these ones, or macys, or whatever). basically i'm apologizing for this crap. it was all written way before i knew what i was doing (2010), and through a series of circumstances ended up being recorded, hastily. i hope that makes sense

002783.question: just wondering what's the chord change at the end of your 'what is love?' video? (i.e. the 'hell yeah' one)
002783.answer: key is Bb, and i will tell you the notes. on "hell," bass is F, melody is C. important harmony notes are Eb and Gb, less important is Bb (NOT A, A WOULD RUIN THIS). and "yeah" is just Bb maj triad (Bb, D, F). to express it in terms of chord symbols, you might accurately say F7sus4b9, or Ebmin6 over F, or Cdim (or half dim, NOT dim7) over F. all would be equally accurate. the important note that makes the magic happen is the Gb, and it is the same note that makes 4min chords happen. i hope that answers your question

002797.question: you used to decide what to work on according to length, then with a randomizer, and it seems now you're trying to pretty evenly distribute music/short stuff/long videos over time. are you using any sort of system now to decide what to work on?
002797.answer: i am now "writing the queue" in a more human way than ever before, and i think that is a breakthrough for me. the short videos (including 'what is love') were all newly written as i made the queue (not selected from the archive). i have added some songs to the queue which i HAVE picked randomly, but I'm doing it differently than before -- now I'm actually randomizing from the entire list of songs including ones that are not 100% done (writing), where as before i would only pick from the completed list, and as a result the ones selected were always very old, because the newer ones are usually unfinished (writing). but now i have actually made a list that includes all the partially written ones (including ones that are just a title, or just one line, or even just an idea.) and whatever gets picked, i have to write it to completion. as a result, the finished items will include more newer and stronger writing. So far 3 song picks have been made, the first one was about 50% done, the second one was 100% done but i changed part of it, and the third one was really just a short (very traditional) chord form with barely a dummy melody, and i finished and wrote the whole thing. The entire current queue of items was made/selected/written between 5/20 and 5/26, and it has 11 items, starting with "thinkin bout doing some content." after those 11 items, there is a history video which is currently only a title. after picking that title, i decided to start production on the videos. The list may change, and i am trying very hard to resist the hammering from the public to "just do another history video" and i am trying very hard to remember that no one was asking for a history video before i did it (they wanted vines forever), and that following through in my own way is what made that what it was, and i am trying to remember to continue operating like that.

002802.answer: go for years and years with a steadily increasing desire to create any and every type of video and music content, and continue to be tortured by the inability to find where to start, and i think you might find that making a schedule like this one is quite an effective life raft. then, in trying to implement a schedule as intensive as that one, i think you will realize that it is impossible to do long content very often. if it occurs to you to start posting the material on a specific popular app (vine) built for short content, and it happens to get you a big following, you might be inclined to continue to make content that fits on that app. then eventually you might lose your mind and try to make long content anyway. then if that succeeds, you might feel like a world of opportunity has opened up (long AND short content) but also still feel a bit tortured as you now have 2 fan bases each distinctively demanding a different length of content

002849.question: i know you've mentioned a few times here that we shouldn't change for anyone or do anything just because someone else wants us to, but you said that in early 2015 you were showing your face in videos quite often then stopped because people didn't like it. Why is that?
002849.answer: that actually wasn't the reason i stopped. i actually didn't stop ..... let me see if i can explain this .... on the original 5-day schedule, i was basically in the video once a week. after taking a break, i came back to a 2 day schedule, which specifically had me appearing once a week (only 2 videos per week.) all those videos got uploaded to vine in a condensed period of time (1 video per day) so when videos from the 2 day schedule went up to vine, that would mean i was appearing every 2 days on vine. and still if you look at the youtube stream, it is every other video. those videos were coming out monday and thursday. so it's still once a week. after the vine content horizon, i had to start actually making 7 days a week to maintain the 7 day schedule on vine, and i decided to preserve the monday/thursday formats, and just surround them with jingles. thursday's format shifted to band videos instead of spoken 1-liners, but it was still a chance for me to be in the video. still once a week. throughout the following months, that mostly stayed the same. i may have missed a couple thursdays, and also tried to make up for it. but i continued to appear in them roughly once a week, all the way through the majority of the time working on history of japan, all the way up until the point when i finally quit doing vines in order to finish history of japan. then history of japan came out, and i decided to build a journal page and edit 6 years worth of journals, and also build improv pages and do improv edits. (which by the way, i do appear in some of). so overall i don't think there is a very convincing argument that i stopped. although it is true that during the time when the 2 day schedule was going up to vine, there were people who indicated that they were tired of seeing me every other day. but there was nothing i could do about it, because i was uploading all the videos in order. i do think it is important to appear in videos reasonably often, because i don't want it to be shocking when i do

002882.question: What do you do for your own entertainment?
002882.answer: hardly anything anymore. i am trying so hard to finish what i have started. some of the unproductive things i used to enjoy doing are anagrams, jamming out with myself sloppily on jazz tunes or other cover tunes, studying the history of the world, studying historic maps, walking insanely long distances through cities and towns, particularly on roads that are the original historic roads, ..... many of these things i have actually managed to work into my career in a productive way (history, anagrams...) and i have posted many of the jazz jam sessions in an obscure section of my website. but really i can't afford to lose any time now. there is just too much work to do. so i try to make sure everything is directed toward the video and/or music content that i am releasing, in a timely manner

002883.question: Is there coming a new big video out soon like the history of japan? or nah?
002883.answer: i am heavily divided right now. history and/or research videos is enormously important, and i want to do as many as possible, but also releasing a huge amount of songs (including ones in the 2 or 3 minute range) is something i have been working toward for most of my life. (i spent all of 2012 and 2013 writing!) so if i don't figure that out soon, my life will explode. But i also don't want to drop the research/history thing, because it is also very important to me, and i know many many people are also eagerly awaiting it. i am trying to figure out how to not fragment my career. yesterday i actually started writing a research/history video, and i am very confident in where it's going, but i am also gravely aware that if i don't jump seriously into recording songs in large quantities, i may die. that being said, i have a 1 minute song all set with video that will be coming out next week, which might help kick things off. i'm really not sure if i'm going to push full speed ahead with this history video now, or try to push forward with songs, or whatever. reaching this decision is exactly what i will be doing for the next couple days. it is very precarious

002884.question: Have you already made your full length songs? When will you post them?
002884.answer: during the last 5, no fuck it, 7 years, i have been writing them in massive, massive quantities. i started recording a few of them in 2009 and continued to reacord many throughout 2010. but i also kept writing even more. then i wrote more. then i recorded a few in 2011, and stlil wrote more. some of them were fragments. in 2012 i started organizing the fragments and writing on all of them, and finishing many of them. i wrote constantly with no recording for the next couple years. in 2014 i started making short videos regularly, and recording a song (picked from the archive) once a week. but the longer ones couldn't really get done that often because i was on such a tight schedule. the success i've had with videos has gotten in the way of having time to do songs. research videos also became important to me, so i had to tackle that. now that that door is at least opened, i think it's time to think about songs. to clarify, every song i've ever recorded has been released (except for maybe 1 or 2 which came out really bad). there are many many many many more written, and many more partially written, and i feel like my songwriting is in a better place now than ever before, after all the practice i got in 2012/13, as well as all the practice i got doing all those jingle vines. i probably over answered your question. Trust me, if i had stuff recorded, i would post it. the defining problem of my life is that i can't record nearly as fast as i can write

002979.question: So hopefully this question isn't too personal for your tastes - and if it is, I hope you choose to answer it by means other than this page - because honestly, I am baffled by you. You often mention feelings of loneliness, and I wonder if this is actually how you feel, or if it's part of the self-deprecating humour routine. It boggles me, because you seem absolutely content with being alone, and I know that personally, if I had the chance to meet you or even write together, I would grab it immediately. As a girl freshly graduated from college and trying to figure out the path of sharing my ideas with the world, watching what you do is inspiring to me. So thank you for doing what you love, and thank you for giving it out for others to see. :)
002979.answer: i have mentioned this before, but it was reluctantly that i decided to really start working alone. but ever since i did, it has worked very well and the loneliness is much more tolerable and organized. it doesn't feel 'wrong' like it did before, but it is still there. it is especially strong when i feel up against the wall about lengths of projects -- i want to do longer projects and i think most people want me to, but they take so long that it means nothing gets posted in the mean time. that's kind of when i feel the most lonely-- there's no one that really is with me during that struggle.

003035.question: I'm not really that good at writing music but I like to make it anyway. I've been using GarageBand for instrumentals and Notes for lyrics. I don't think it'll amount to anything and I sometimes wonder if I took music theory classes, which I don't want to take, whether I would get better and whether it would be worth it. Basically what it boils down to is "do I want to waste my time doing something that will help in the long run but that I really don't want to do and that I don't need or do I want to teach myself and get better agonizingly slowly but have a lot more fun doing it"
003035.answer: news flash.... the fact that you "don't want" to learn "music theory" is a sneak preview that you are not going to learn it if you expect someone else to teach it to you. that's just the nature of "music theory" and/or ... the nature of learning in general, i think! you can't just go to the doctor and get a 'shot' of 'music theory' and know it. besides ..... it doesn't really exist!! the way "music" "theory" (if there is such a thing) works is .... it's really just how you choose to make sense of the musical world you live in. Every "music theory" class really is just an extrapolation of what seems to be the principles among a CERTAIN SET of music that was popular during a certain time period. If you go to a classical school, they will teach you things that relate to what was popular in europe several centuries ago. if you go to berklee, they will probably teach you a lot about what was popular in the 1940s. there could be a class based on only the last 20 years of music, and it would be different still. there is really only a small amount of stuff that is really actually established and unchanging. like note names -- europe named the notes with letters a few centuries ago, and it really stuck. the entire world uses those notes. do you know them? (A, Bb, B, C, etc) i've known many many musicians in my life, and also many people who were in music school, and anyone who really gets how music works did not learn it from a class. they may have been in a class, but what is really going to give you the knowledge is going to come from you. and it will need to happen in your own way. in other words, i have absolutely never met anyone that had music theory entirely 'bestowed' or given to them from only an outside source. i've said this many times, but really the best way to go about it is from the context of music you know and like. Learn that music! learn how to play it. learn how to play those melodies. learn how to play those chords. (and don't expect a chord to always have 3 notes or always be next to each other!) Learn the music you already know. you Will find principles, and you will get to know them very well. THEN, later on, perhaps you will stumble upon a music textbook or something, and 'take a glance' inside, ... and you will probably start to find things that you are familiar with, and maybe you will learn a name or 2. But really that's just learning the names of something you already knew. That won't actually make you 'better,' it only helps in the sense that it helps you communicate with other musicians in a working situation. But that only goes so far, because the majority of musicians (including professionals) really don't know 'official music theory' that deeply, regardless of how experienced they may be. Again, there really is no 'official music theory' beyond a couple very small things -- note names ... and key signatures i guess. Everything else will be stylistically catered to the way music might have been played at a certain time in history. so that is why you are best off approaching it from exactly the standpoint that you are used to. i hope that answers your question

003064.question: Do you have any advice for people who want to sing and play (bass, for example) at the same time? Or is it just "practice makes perfect" ??
003064.answer: just start doing it. playing and singing together will feel like its own instrument. for bass, you absolutely must play in a band to really get any experience, i think. for piano + singing, for example, that's something that works well all by itself, and i should mention that regardless of vocal, piano in a band and piano outside of a band are also like 2 different instruments (the work is divided completely differently between your hands). for bass, one of the confusing things you will run into is note duration (length of notes) which is very important for the bass, and it will be confusing at first to get those right while trying to sing something which will have different note durations. but experience will do the trick. will lee did it on TV four days a week for 30 years and he got it down pretty good (well, the singing part wasn't usually on TV, but it happened during the break)

003111.question: when do you think your next history video will be done?
003111.answer: i am about 30 to 45 seconds into the writing. i really like the direction that it is going. i am using the same strategy as i did for history of japan, which is "say as much as you need to say to sufficiently explain the topic FAST and efficiently, but make it as long as you need." when the writing is done, i will do a timed read through and then i will know how long it is. i am guessing it will be anywhere between 5 and 10 minutes. (if i can say everything i want to say in 3, that would be fine too. if it takes 15, ...... i guess that's fine too.) japan clocked in at exactly 9 minutes on the first timed run through. i am also working on this video every day, every available hour (just like the last one.) The main difference between this time and last time is this: during the 14 weeks that it took to make history of japan, i was also writing and creating short videos for vine Every Single Day for about the first 2/3 of the time i was working on history of japan. so that would be maybe about half the work time each day devoted to vine, and NOT the history video. Now i am not doing that. so that would be a significant reason why this video might get done faster. Also, after making history of japan, i have refined some of my techniques a bit more, and might be able to work faster. However, the scope of this topic is a bit different, which might present some unforseen challenges. There is also a small chance that I may decide to make a short video just to have Something to release during the long haul (although i might NOT do that, because that will only directly delay the release of the long video.) The good news is, i have a 1 minute song and music video already completed which i am waiting to upload. i am saving it for when i am deep in the depths of production on this long video, so i have something to release. i hope that answers your question

003119.answer: they are similar, and were written in a similar time. sort of experimental. kind of like the feeling of being a puddle of liquid on a hot sidewalk. this would also go for the songs surrounding it during that time period (BEFORE "what love is"). honestly, these songs have an experimental quality that i would not necessarily recommend. i think i was trying to compensate for the random unpredictable quality that my songs had had previously

003120.question: What's the history of "i can play"? (I can't get this song out of my head.)
003120.answer: it was originally written in 2 different 2010 library sessions. here is the chart for the original version. as you can see there are 2 dates on the top, i think the split point is somewhere at the end of the second chorus, that's where i stopped and picked up again in the second session. that was in 2010, and it looks like all the lyrics and sections and pretty much the whole song was there. in 2013, i looked at it again, and made an update. here is the 2013 update it looks like it was transposed, and the chords are clarified and slightly adjusted throughout. but the biggest change is the second chorus -- looks like the second chorus was totally re-written, and now goes on a harmonic adventure through key changes. and the end vamp is re-worked. the song was recorded in 2014 for a wednesday song release, and these charts are obeyed almost exactly. on a tight weekly/daily schedule, as with most of the releases in 2014, any song over 30 seconds is under severe time constraints in the production process, so as a result this recording is very hasty, and i hardly had time to mix the vocal at all, so some of the lines are too loud, and the whole thing is pretty hasty

003121.question: From bo's ama "In getting an audience early, I realized how incredibly fluky and volatile peopleŐs attention was. And that trying to control it directly was impossible. The only thing I ever have had control of was the actual work. And for me, the corny truth at the center of it is that you should try to follow your impulse to GIVE something to people, not the impulse to get something from them. I try to tell myself to just shut the fuck up and work hard on something that I think is good and important and make it as good as I can and when IŐm done with it, share it. Self-promotion should be the last step, not the first. But also I got super lucky and didnŐt have to promote myself so IŐm a bit of a privileged hypocrite Đ but like that self-branding shit is pretty gross and I just think like makes you feel icky and unsatisfied and I donŐt think leads to happiness even when it works."

003132.question: If I donate $50, what would you do with the money? Will it mean more time to make strange videos?

003153.question: Written songs keep piling up, and I'm never satisfied with what I have already recorded. Mixing issues, mostly: bass too loud, sibilance, etc etc. To relieve stress, more songwriting takes place, and at the same time, no new recording takes places because it feels "wrong" to move on until those old recordings are "OK". Somtimes, I get on a roll of "just doing it" (like what u said about demon-killing songs), and it feels so, so great! The experience stacks up, and slowly things start feeling smoother, it flows. But at some point I will always look back at the first recordings and think, "that was a good song, but it's recorded terribly. Maybe I should go back..." and that halts the whole flow. I guess there's no real answer to this situation, but I'm wondering if, besides the demon-killing, did you set yourself any "limits" too? Like, "once a song is recorded, that's it"? It takes so much willpower to do, but I guess sometimes songs n eed to b e used as fuel to kindle the fire of future songs. Or something. It's hard!!!

003179.question: what was the inspiration for "im crazy / it's raining"?
003179.answer: written in early 2012, i sort of was exhaused from all the years gone by of trying to write really crazy stuff, and then trying to write really normal stuff (2011) and just in general so much time had gone by trying to write in different ways, trying to improvise in different ways, writing in text (which goes back even further) .... just feeling like i had tried everything and yet i still hadn't made any of it public yet. crazy/raining sort of was like that peaceful yet kind of hopeless feeling of "well, i think i've tried absolutely everything, i've tried more things, i've tried less things, i've tried not trying things, i've tried trying too many things, ..... and i still haven't really put it together. and i have no energy left. where am i now?" there is this feeling of being totally exhausted from trying everything, and yet, the steady "rain" still falls -- the steady rain of you still wanting to do all the things you want to do. the steady feeling that you STILL want to express yourself in crazy and/or meaningful ways. the fact that even if you feel totally drained and dead, the rain still falls. that's sort of why the song sounds very plain and doesn't really have any creative melody tricks, or any strange lyrics, .... it's just like rain. i've always debated whether to record it, because i wasn't sure if it was too boring. but it came up on a randomized selection in 2015, and i reluctantly gave it a shot

003183.question: kind of curious, how was the transition to long-form content in history of japan? was there anything about the process that was noticeably different/unique from making vines and songs? and i'm guessing it was also different starting from researched work on a random topic and trying to make it "your own" versus being inspired by events in your life (which seems to be how you usually get ideas)- did that trip you up any?
003183.answer: Everything is different when you increase the length of the project. even things you wouldn't expect to be different. and going from 7 seconds to 9 minutes is a huge difference. i already noticed how different things were when i made some 2 and 3 minute music videos earlier that year. every possible element of the project becomes very different, and new challenges are raised. one unexpected example is, processing power. when i was doing history of japan, by about 3 minutes in, the computer slowed down to the point where i couldn't do anything. and there were actually glitches starting to occur on the render!! so ultimately what i had to do was split the project up into chapters, no longer than about 1 minute. and very carefully allign them so that i could seamlessly export one and import it into the next sequence. i did the same thing when doing score. this is just one example of the many things that are unexpectedly different when the project size changes

003188.question: It's so cool you are answering this questions! So, what's the origin / inspiration for "I like"? And what about that cheeky first part?
003188.answer: again, just breaking lots of rules and experimenting. creating hopelessly stupid lyrics, and seeing if i can save it. i suppose there is one very meaningful line in there: "it's so hard to remember what you're doing until it's done." i feel like that is a victory moment in the song, because up until then nothing has really made sense, but when you get to that line, it almost feels like everything has made sense all along .... and the line is even explaining that phenomenon as it happens. and perhaps the section that comes after that (can't see you, etc) is just the "non-caring" "i-already-did-something" "i-can-disappear-now" steam that rises in the aftermath. write date would be early august 2010 (the original chart should be on the site). song didn't get recorded until early 2011, and the video didn't get made until 2014.

003192.question: what's "the road" about? (which road, specifically?)
003192.answer: more of a writing experiment. written in early 2012. hadn't written anything in a long time, and 2011 was more about chasing 'normal' writing techniques, and writing using text and recorders, using verse-chorus form, etc... But at this point i was getting restless and missed the days when i used to write songs on paper, beginning to end, in the library. (string-writing, or chain-writing ... train-writing .. whatever you want to call it). So i just hit the page, and 'the road' came out. i just went wherever i wanted to go, and the whole thing stays about equal melodic and harmonic density, yet without any real repeating patterns of any kind. changes keys all over the place. a fun time to get really frisky with key changes. might be inspired by some of the crazier donald fagan writing. the lyrics just came out automatically. everything changes after the "now i know" part .... and i'm not sure exactly what that means. in a song like this about "searching" it might seem surprising to eventually "find" the thing! but it just happened. and the mood sounds a bit strange after that, especially converging on the last line (which i didn't know was going to be the title until the end) .... almost feels like i'm saying everything's fine and i found my way, but it's obvious listening to the harmonic mood that something's not totally cool.

003222.question: how did you got inspired for making the song and vid of new canaan? i really love it
003222.answer: was in penn station one time and i was just like 'damn, there's trains here that go to the entire world, i just pick somewhere and see what's there. even if it's nothing, i don't care, i want to go.' so 4 different times that month (may 2009) i took a songbook and went to a random place, and wrote a song on the way. new canaan got some very very small edits (mainly in the last verse) in 2012. got recorded in 2014 on the wednesday song schedule. then it came up for a tuesday music video a few months later, and being almost 3 minutes, it was extremely ambitious to fit in to the schedule... basically means i had to do the video in about 1 day, which is why it is Extremely low budget... just did like 1 full length vocal take, 1 drum take, maybe did a couple specific bass fills.... and there's hardly any graphics... the occasional train or map just barely makes it interesting enough. ultimately i'm glad it got recorded, it was very high on my most-wanted list (mainly because of that license plate line, honestly) for many years

003354.question: How long did alphabet shuffle take, and what was its backstory?
003354.answer: looks like i created the music proj file june 4, and the final video was done june 14. this doesn't really include the writing. although the last line of the bridge (alright, etc) was written this month. Original idea is from early 2012. it's a floater, it's been kicking around in the system for a while, and got finished little bits at a time. 10.18.13 looks like i solidified the chord specifics of the "tags" (the extra wxyz's, etc) and also started the bridge (up until 'i'm alive'). then last month when i was trying to find a path back into songs (and start actually choosing songs for once instead of randomizing them) this one was the only sensible starting point. and i finished the bridge and just settled for basic "AABA" form, and figured if anyone complains there's no jokes, oh well. The video making went surprisingly fast. was able to really just screenshot the letters and import them fast and just start messing with them without having a plan. looking forward to being that bold in the future

003360.question: what inspired you to create the video time mop
003360.answer: that was actually an old instrumental, from 2009 (there were actually 4 in a row). recorded them very spontaneously, making bold /brash moves. an effort to shock myself out of non-recording (i had already started to write, but i still hadn't recorded any of it.) the video wasn't until 2014. i was doing music videos (from previously recorded songs... usually ones with lyrics) twice a week. but it's a whole different game when you make a video based on an existing instrumental recording. there's no lyrics or content, or plot points, or anything! what the hell do you put in the video? it was a fun challenge to see what happens in the video. the other main example is the video for 'no castle', also instrumental, where again the track is much older than the video, and it is an experiment to see if you can find things out of nowhere to put in the video, to match the music

Here a polite question, though; why have you linked to iTunes and Spotify at the end of the video when neither is really where your content is at? Surely the primary links at the end of your vid should be your site and Patreon, no? PLEASE excuse me if I come across as rude. I don't mean to be.
003364.answer: well, i prefer to just post songs on simple websites to download, like a reasonable person. but for some reason most of the world thinks it's reasonable to get their music through either itunes or spotify. (plus, who knows, if my numbers there ever get to the numbers i've had on vine or youtube, that could mean i finally actually get to earn something!) there's like 1000 songs i still need to record, and i've been waiting to really get started on that for a Long Time. it's just like the Research Video Situation before i did a research video, if that makes sense. So if i can launch a bit more of a following on itunes/spotif, that would be great news for the music -- because no one on spotify is ever going to be mad that i didn't put out a history video on spotify.

003488.question: Hey Bill, love your music. I wanted to ask, do you generally prefer to retain a midi/synth-centric sound or is it a matter of necessity at the moment? If you had the resources to use more real instruments would you? Thanks!
003488.answer: music can be made out of anything. i firmly believe this. i was raised with access to midi, and my mom actually showed me how it works when i was about 10. i didn't pick up any kind of guitar until i was at least 15. i did try recording audio (non-midi) somewhere around that time, but there was no more freedom. i couldn't change and adjust parts with anywhere near the same freedom that i could with midi. Sure, you can make great and crazy sounds with audio, but i am not a soundsmith. my strength is in the notes, chords, and thankfully i have now found a way to put words into the mix as well. Recording using audio would be an entirely different animal. an entirely different world. a great world, but completely, completely different. it's about as likely for me to suddenly switch to that as it is for me to suddenly become a professional golfer. also, i think this midi approach has a lot of advantages if you have to work alone. i can fly around between different instruments and make adjustments very quickly, which cushions the damage of the 'alone problem' -- the problem where the first instrument can't hear the later instruments being played and can't react to them. Sure, in audio you can do 'punches' but it still seems limited, and it's just a whole diffent game, plus you probably also need more processing power and i have zero life experience working that way, or thinking that way. i've been doing midi since i was 10. for my situation, the advantages of using midi are insane. The only instrument i use audio for is the vocal, because you have to. and that's more than enough to manage. also with recording audio, you have to actually worry about sound quality, mic quality, all kinds of stuff. and these are things that i have Never worried about. I have been made to feel guilty on multiple occasions for using MIDI, and i used to feel guilty about it then, but then i realized that i have heard plenty of artists use MIDI in amazing ways, so at a certain point i really started to embrace it and never looked back. the thing that i probably envy most in the audio world is stuff like strumming guitars, etc. I do think it is eventually worth it to try to conquer the audio mountain in order to include some of those things, but it would be a huge huge change, and require me to learn to think and function in entirely new ways. also you would now have to worry about guitar quality!! worry about the strings, worry about intonation, worry about amps maybe, worry about miking, on and on, more and more issues that i have never even touched. not to mention another even bigger issue: working with other people. using audio would require me to go back to the stone age in many, many, many ways. and i would do it immediately if i could live forever. perhaps i would also become a molecular biologist

003508.question: What is the best way to write lyrics? I'm always struggling with that. It's hard to find rhymes that make sense and mine always sound so cheesy
003508.answer: NEVER CHASE THE RHYME. there is nothing worse than a contrived rhyme. Also, when you chase rhymes, that implies that all your lines will be in sets of 2 that are all the same length. that's just not the way it has to work. Really just open your mind up and take it moment by moment. ask yourself what could you do at each moment that would excite You? you would be surprised how often rhymes show up automatically. but another important thing to remember about "rhymes" in music, --- it really doesn't matter if the consonants rhyme. it really just matters if the vowel rhymes. in music, "fine" and "time" rhyme. no one will ever complain about that. i like to stretch it even more, and sometimes it is actually enjoyable when you break the rhyme. but i will say this again, ...... do not chase the rhyme. the rhymes will always come to you if the time is right. also i should probably mention that i only write lyrics together with the melody. if you are writing only lyrics without a melody, i can understand why you might think you need to search for rhymes. but if put it to a melody, what you will find that the rhymes will want to be in all different places, and the rhymes that you had on paper pre-melody will no longer work. Really what i'm trying to say is, there is absolutely no rules, remain open, and have fun. and never chase rhymes, you will find them coming to you when the time is right

003527.question: Is this correct: Chords : Eb Ebsus2 Ab Absus2 I’m going to New Canaan, Pennsylvania Eb Ebsus2 Bb I’m going to New Canaan for a late night snack Ab Absus2 Gm7 Cm7 and by late night I mean middle of the afternoon Fm Bb Eb Ebsus4 Eb Ebsus4 and i’m never coming back Ab Absus4 Ab Absus2 Let me stop in Harlem to explain what I mean Ab Cm Bb7 i’m actually going to Connecticut Ab Bb Eb Gm Ab Bb Bbsus2 Eb Ebsus4 Eb Ebsus2 oh i’m going to New Canaan, Pennsylvania to have a good time Eb Ebsus2 Ab Absus2 i’m riding on a good old fashioned train Eb Ebsus2 Bb I hope that good old fashioned train don’t get de-railed Ab Absus2 Gm7 Cm7 I’m hungry and starving for food and women, Fm Bb7(?) Eb Ebsus4 Eb Ebsus4 But I ain’t gonna turn back yet. Eb Bb Ab Eb The season is winter and the sky is so blue Ab Cm7 Bbsus4 Bb I am so blue for you Eb Bb Ab Eb It feels just like summer and my nose is blue Ab Cm7 Gm7 Cm7 Cause I lie about details when my dreams don’t come true Ab Ab/G Fm7 And I always feel for you Fm7 Bb Eb Ab Bb Eb Fm7 Bb7(?) Every word I say is true Eb Ebsus2 Ab Absus2 I’m going on a journey to the countryside Fm7 Bb Bb/B (?) I’m going on a trip to see what I can find Ab Absus2 Gm7 Cm7 Looks like a 12-figure income town Fm7 Bb7 Eb Ebsus2 Abm7 (?) But I love the shade of those license plates Ab Absus2 Ab I’m gonna go to Starbucks and play my ukulele Cm7 Bbsus2 Under the bright blue sky Ab Gm7 Fm7 Bb7 Eb Ebsus2 Eb Ebsus2 I’m going to New Canaan and everything feels just right. Eb Bb Ab Eb oh, it’s summer and the sky has turned grey, Ab Cm7 Bbsus4 Bb my dreams are sailing away. Eb Bb Ab Eb I’m going crazy, and i’m feeling blue, Fm7 Cm7 cause I know where i’m going, Gm7 Cm7 Ab Ab/G Fm7 but not what to do and I always dream of you Fm7 Bb7 Eb Ebsus2 Ab Bb etc…. Every word I say is true.
003527.answer: pretty good, but there are a few mistakes, some more important than others. the sus2's you have at the beginning of the verses are not really strictly obeyed. that's just kind of the way i played it. i would honestly just think "Eb" or "Ab." 2's will sneak in, that would be a players choice. and surely there will be times where you can catch me playing 2's and 3's at the same time. but that's not too important. The next thing i see is at the end of the first stanza, after "never coming back" -- the Ebsus4's you have written -- it should include a 2 also. however you choose to say that (Ebsus2,4?? sus4,2??who knows). the first mistake that actually matters is the Bb7 on connecticut. it's Bb7sus4. actually there's a C note in there too. but NO D. i can firmly say in this song you will not hear Ab and D notes played at the same time. when i use D in the chord, it's just a Bb triad (as you have correctly noted, mostly). so that's a Bb7sus4 or Bb9sus4. (or Fmin7 over Bb if that's not too confusing) ok moving on, the pickup notes on "oh, i'm" i would definitely specify the bass notes there -- Ab/C, Bb/D. immediately after that, you said Gm on "canaan", and it's absolutely not Gm, it's Eb/G. on "have a good time" again, it's Bb7sus4 not Bb or Bbsus2. also for what it's worth, the Ab in that line was played as an "add-2" but that is not important, that's just player's choice. and again, the oscilating chords in the vamp after "good time" includes 2 AND 4. ok, looks good through the train verse, again the 'sus2's are optional and could go either way. "Turn" i see you had a question mark. in most of your question mark situations, the magic note here is B. in this case, it is Bb7sus4b9. so again, i stress the fact that there is no D. but there is a B. call it Abmin6 over Bb, call it Bb7sus4b9, whatever. the magic note is B, and there's no D. and there is a Bb (it's in the melody!) Chorus looks good, just triads, Good job recognizing the Cmin7 (and not Eb) on "blue"!! i always get paranoid that people might not "feel" the 6 bass in those situations when there is no bass. i am glad it came across. on 'You', the sus4 and major really blend together. if i was playing guitar in the key of E, i would be playing B and letting that high E string ring and blend together. but, close enough. on "feel, for, you" i have to nitpick. that is Ab, then Eb/G, then Fmin7. beat by beat. at no point is there Ab/G. last chord before the "countryside" verse, is again Bb7sus4b9. the passing chord after "i can find" -- here's how that works -- the bass is playing A. another important note in the chord is B. the way to really execute this properly is to include G, B, and Eb in the chord, and the bass plays A. call it Gaug over A, call it A9b5, call it Ebaug7 over A, whatever (Db note probably wouldn't hurt in there.) but listening to the reality of what happened, it looks like at least one of the keyboards is not adhering to this. you can hear the B note, but it looks like someone is still playing a Bb note on the transition chord. and guess what, it goes by so fast it does not matter. in plenty of "band" situations, the bass player might choose to play this passing A, and they keyboard/guitar players might not know or care, and it still sounds just find because it goes by so fast. on "shade", again this is Bb7b9sus4 (or again, Abmin6 over Bb. same thing) ok, now clearly you have identified something strange happening here on this chord before the bridge (before "i'm gonna go to starbucks"). the first thing i will say is, it is NOT a 4 chord. the 4 chord is where you are going-- this chord would be the equivalent of a Eb7. more specifically, Ebaug7. there is clearly an F note in there too. you might even call it Gaug7. there might not be a Db. Again, one of the keyboards is somehow still playing a Bb note, which might be "illegal" but it doesn't seem to cause any problems. again, the important note is B, and it's basically just Eb+7. the bass for some reason is allowed to riff freely on Ebmaj pentatonic, not caring about the B nat, because for some reason that's just the way it works. it's a transitionary moment, and you can get away with this. on "starbucks/ukulele" i should comment that the Absus4 is just as legal as it would have been in the "harlem" part, ... it looks like i used it a little less in the 'starbucks' part, although i do hear one of the strings playing that Db note on "play my". on "Sky", again, this is Bb7sus4. and right before "going" the keys slip in that b9 (B note). on "going" with the melody on G, this chord is really happiest emphasizing that G. seems like Abmaj9 with both C and Bb included. on "feels", AGAIN it's Bb7sus4b9. and again, the vamp oscilation is Ebsus2 and 4 together. in the last chorus, there are a couple of bass choices that might be worth pointing out in the chords, but you could just blame that on bass player choices. "dream, of, you" once again is Ab, then Eb/G, then Fmin7 (not Ab/G). and again, for "say", it is Bb7sus4b9. out vamp is correct. near the end, the bass thinks it's doing like a Bdim to Cmin thing, but the keys don't care. so that is probably not even worth writing down. overall, great job

003533.question: I ask you questions thinking you're gonna answer you and you never do.
003533.answer: i usually skip questions asking my what my favorite something is. i simply don't have an answer for that. i also skip questions like "if you could be any type of ______ what would you be." those questions don't make sense to me. there are various other types of questions that i usually skip, but i try to answer absolutely as many questions as possible. i answer so many questions that people say "how do you have time to answer so many questions" !!! and to balance it out, i usually skip that question, because i take that question as a sign that i am answering too many questions. i ultimately should be working on video and music content, so i need to be careful about the amount of time i spend here. another question i get a lot but don't answer is, 'what is my software' because i think it is very unimportant, and if people are looking for advice on software, i ALWAYS recommend starting with the easiest and most readily available. i don't want ANYONE to buy the same program i use just because they think it's going to magically make them make things like me. it won't. it takes years of practice, and it can be done on any software. my software is very cheap and not good. and it also doesn't exist anymore. Also, it is pretty easy to figure out what software i use anyway. that being said, if you have questions that i am not answering, you could try emailing me.

003589.question: Can we get the story behind your song 'do the thing'? I'd really like to hear the thought process behind it, because the lyrics indicate a major change in the singer's behavior. Starting with lines like, "do the thing" and "let me go" but switching to "i don't mind" and "take your time" by the end of it.
003589.answer: this was during a brief period of time when i was actually trying to write in the studio . ... from the beginning of 2011, all i wanted to do was try more "normal" songs (maybe with verse / cho? maybe with just some simple looping chord changes?) also potentially written in the studio. (i eventually concluded that this is a terrible idea for me). experiments in this phase include "when is it time to come home again" "how am i sposed" and "do the thing" .... basically in all 3 cases, i sort of set up the chord vamp, and then i had a text file open and very spontaneously, the lyrics+melody materialized out of thin air. very basic lyrics, very basic melodies. i just let it follow the path of least resistance. "do the thing" is really like a, 'ok universe, i'm ready to go. please show me the way, take me where i'm supposed to go, i'm ready to see what i need to see now.' ... like a real "surrenduring to the sky" type of thing. honestly, after doing so many complex-weird songs with surprises and weird backflips in 2010, i was ready to try the total opposite. so you get this zoned out, almost dead feeling -- for example the huge gap in the lines in the first verse. also, the "i love you" song was recorded at the same time, and that also subscribes to this ultra-dead zoned out feel. was trying this out, probably mostly as a reaction to some of the madness that ensued in all the 2010 songs (only about 10% of which ever got recorded, by the way). So that's what you have for the verses of 'do the thing' (and by the way, 'do the thing' is not a good title, i kept changing the title and never really found the right title for that song). for the bridge, i sort of reverted to "writing mode," stopped the session, and turned to the writing keyboard / paper, and wrote a bridge -- vastly diff. key, probably thinking in "mccartney" mode. trying to do a really "special" bridge. -- by the way, this is also exactly the same strategy for the "what love is" bridge -- stop the session, turn to the book and write a bridge. I don't really have a good explaination for why the last verse of "do the thing" might feel different, to me it was just common sense to arrive at that place. you can feel a little bit of impatience setting in, like "i'll wait forever if i have to" sort of thing. you know, it's that feeling when you are talking to the sky and you know it's the most important conversation ever, but at the same time, ... you might doubt if it even hears you. The tempo decrease makes it seem even more "dying." i was trying new things, again, breaking away from the ultra-complicated, surprise-based writing, and looking to go outside the box on the simple end instead. Go to the store probably goes even further in that direction.

003598.question: When you're writing music (vocal harmonies in particular) do you have the structure mapped out in your head (or on paper) ahead of time before you go about recording each component? Or do you record one track and improvise the harmony over the playback?
003598.answer: doing vocal harmonies to the extent that i do them now is a new thing for me, and i mainly learned it from doing vines every day. but on long songs it's different, because there's so much more territory to cover, and the tendency is to be lazy (because there are so many more miles of song to cover!) -- so here's a new trick i use that allows me to use more harmonies throughout the song without becoming exhaused-- i build it from the lead, and i just pitch shift it all over the place! that's how i write it. so this would be during the recording process, once i have a vocal (or actually the temp vocal) i just make it from the computer -- this encourages me to try crazy things. one of the first times i did this was on "free to do whatever you want to" -- for example, there is one near the end of the bridge (i think on "can't get over my fear") ... i never would have thought to do that if i was like, ready to record, quick what should i sing . if i'm sitting around and i can just pitch the lead anywhere, i am free to try really crazy stuff. and in the end, whatever i pick is not that hard to sing. so then i just learn it and sing it, and delete the fake one. and now it sounds just as cool, but it's real! so basically, writing it from the computer lets me try out things really quickly, and be really ambitious. then once i get the part, i just learn it and deliver it. On vines, this really doesn't apply, or also on those dense all-chord jingles in history of japan. Those are all being written note for note when i first write it. and it's become a very sensitive thing. a jingle like "it's time for world war 1" i will be sitting at the keyboard meticulously trying different things until the chords are exactly right. And then when i record it, it's pretty simple -- you just sing all the notes of the chords, (taking various other basic considerations). doing vines 7 days a week really accelerated my vocal harmony game, and i'm looking forward to doing much much more of it in the future

003607.question: hello! since you use your keyboard for drums, do you mix your drums in seperate channels (for snare, kick, hi-hats, etc), or the whole drum machine as one channel?
003607.answer: what i have learned is, it IS smart to mix the kick separate. why? because reverb on the kick is usually a bad idea, but you might want a little rev on the rest. so i actually developed a cool technique to quickly separate it out -- i duplicate the channel, and delete all the kicks in one, and delete all the 'everything else' in the other. that's about it. i could separate it more, but life is short. if i'm doing a song with not much reverb, i might not even bother

003611.question: I've been trying to crack down on hand independence on the piano recently. What tips can you give to a semi-beginner to help with hand independence? Thanks <3
003611.answer: i'm not sure. i just kind of do what i need to do. There are a few different "worlds" of playing piano -- one where you play bass with your left hand, chords with your right hand, and sing the melody. there is another world (like if you are in a band) where the bass player plays the bass, and a singer or horn player plays the melody, and just play chords with whatever hand you want. then there is another world like a jazz trio where the bass player plays the bass and you play chords with your left hand and melody with your right hand. and there is another world where you are by yourself and not singing, so you have somehow play all 3 with 2 hands. depending on which world you are in, you would practice different things

003614.question: when you're composing, i'm assuming you sit at the keyboard and hash it out, but are you hyperscribing that into Finale/or-whatever? or do you flesh it out in your fingers/brain first and notate it in f or sequencing/composing later?
003614.answer: i never use computer notation programs -- i only do that when i want to use notation in videos. whenever i use notation for writing, i do it on paper, it's much faster. from 2009-2010 i actually wrote everything on paper first, not even using an instrument, i actually did most of it in the library. you can see many of these charts on the site, so you can see the level of detail it includes. it includes exact melody, lyrics, and chords, but not really all the little details of drum parts or aux parts. it will usually have a tempo marking, and sometimes a 'hint' at what the groove should sound like, maybe just referencing another song. but the details of the groove and the little background parts are all worked out during the recording. but the 'road map' (how many bars in each section, how to end it, what the intro is, especially the lengths of things) HAS to be solid before recording. i found that out the hard way. you can't be wondering how it should end when you're recording it. road map has to be set, that's just what i learned. ... Ok, that being said, starting in 2011 i actually learned how to write using a keyboard and voice memo recordings. for a long time i didn't do this because i didn't know how to brainstorm and keep it organized, but i finally figured out how to do it, and wrote like this ever since -- including the massive amount of revisions and updates i made to the existing song catalog during 2012-13. basically there is a master text file, which has a lyric sheet, and every part has a reference audio file that goes with it -- so the text will have the lyric, and then at the end of the stanza or whatever, it would say "see audio 27.mov" and that would be just a desk recording of me demoing how it goes, and perhaps giving other instructions or indications of how to deliver it. sometimes even when the song is done, i might do a paste-together of all these demos, or just do a full run through with a click. occasionally i still might use paper, especially if i have a bridge or something that has really interesting changes, but these days i find it's not even worth it -- does not make for easy access, because it would be buried in a book somewhere and i can't 'search' for the file. Before recording a song, i find it very helpful to make a "studio chart" which is actually just mainly a chord chart, and it also has specific rhythmic indications of when to play certain chords (particularly when certain chords need to be anticipated)

003749.question: In your video "the high class stuff", how did you animate the sheet music?
003749.answer: i will explain a single page first (the multi-page spread is another issue)... let's say there is just one page of notation, like 8 bars or whatever.... I make the notation in a notation program, and screenshot it. (then i actually make several allignment adjustments in graphics, because notation programs are incredibly finicky, it's easier to adjust things in graphics)... then i save it how i want. then i use graphics to erase the last note (and any chord that goes along with it.) i erase notes on a staff by just dragging empty staff over it. and i "save as" and then add a 1 to the file name. repeat, keep erasing the next note and 'save as'. then you have a stack of files all in order. then import. then allign the timing. it's the exact same way i do text, but with text i type it out and screenshot each frame, and delete words (easier, instead of erasing them). the delete technique would not work in a notation program, because the notes and allignment will change as you delete them. that's why i use graphics. it's not that hard, and i'm not even using a graphics program. just an image preview program, and i'm just copying and pasting boxes. the mccartney video was a bit more ambitious because i wanted to do a steady scroll. so i thought it would be good to make one huge image file that is the entire length of the score. and then do the erase per frame technique.... so then all the frames were huge... and then export that to a really high res video and scroll the video??? i don't remember if this was successful, but you run into major problems when you try to do huge things like that. processing power limitations, etc. Same sort of crisis occured when i was trying to do the zoom out on the japanese army. i ended up having to sonehow break the task into smaller pieces. if i recall. i somehow succeeded in gettiing a steady scroll on the notation, only to find out that it was too hard to read when it's moving like that!! so i ended up keeping it still and then sliding forward page by page. if i had known the steady scroll wasn't going to work, i probably would have broken it into pages from the start. i was on a 7 day vine schedule at that time, so that video was an insane time crunch, and the notation took me from about 3am straight through the entire day until 4 pm and was barely on time for work. (not to mention COMPOSING the rhythms and chords, and composing the notation, before animating it.) it was a bad and unhealthy time crunch. i suppose thats what you get for attempting a 30 sec (45 sec? whatever it is) video in place of a 6 second video. was in such a rush, there is a smudge in the youtube version (a stray piece of a note that didn't get erased fully)

003786.question: Do you find yourself wanting to create things that YOU want to make, or do you want to create things OTHERS want to see? Like, percentage wise, i mean. (Personally i'm like 90% me/10% others.) This is a topic that fascinates me for some reason.

003795.question: What was the thinking behind the series where you sang about objects or other random live video (i.e. not graphics)? Such as bread, tape, iron my shoes, colonization, mail you my floor
003795.answer: it was just a good way to start out making videos when i didn't really know what to do, but felt like i could do anything. the first 3 were done in 2011 (bed, bowl, foot) and then i didn't do any videos for a long time (was mostly writing and recording songs.) then in 2014 i spontaneously put together a 5-day video schedule (actually 4 videos and a song) and i tried to break it up into categories of formats i wanted to explore, which included graphics / non-graphics, and also included 'based on an existing song' or 'completely free written.' So with free or non-free, and graphics and non-graphics, that makes 4 types of videos. live action free videos were on thursday, and started with 'stand in my room' and just moved forward with anything i could find. a lot of jingles about objects. that's just the way it went. after the break (early 2015) and returning to a 2-day schedule, the live action videos were based on improvised 1-liners, with intro and/or outtro screens to justify.
