003797.question: How do you get to know yourself?

003798.question: After following your stuff now for a bit, I think I see now that you really just want to make everything that you can possibly make. (A fascinating pursuit, even if it's a bit strange.) What I'm wondering though, is what this means for quality control? So, for instance, would you rather create 100 kind-of okay-ish videos/songs, or 1 really really good one? And if you found one specific thing that meant the world to you, would you be willing to drop everything to work on just that project, or would you rather be working on having more "things" done for people to see at the end of the day? (sorry for this question being so wordy, i almost feel bad making you read all this)
003798.answer: i am trying to do the best stuff i can. but sometimes if you are thinking like that, you won't do anything. at a certain point, you realize that every song or story is only good because there is something wrong with it. the main character has to have a problem in order for the story to mean anything. music has to have something 'bad' or 'wrong' about it, in order for you to feel the healing from that problem. So the more you try to search for the 'perfect' song, you will only realize that the only perfect song is total silence..... which is pointless. Over and over again i have tried to hone in on the "right music" and it continues to be impossible, and that is what has always led me to just dig in and start going crazy. in the end, i am a perfectionist, so even if i work on a very strange song or project, i am still going to take care to make sure that it is as good as possible. Also, very important to remember, is that the more you do, the better you get. this is the wheezy waiter "quantity+quality" theory. you are really never going to discover what you are truly capable of unless you try many different things. if you sit around and wait for something better and better, you will get no experience and you will chicken out because you will be afraid it won't be good enough. that being said, i am currently working on a video that is longer than any video i have ever made, and it will probably take longer to make than any video i have ever made. so i'm not sure where that fits into your equation of "100 okay-ish videos"

003811.question: Could you give a list of the songs that you primarily wrote using your murder your demon technique?
003811.answer: hard to define which ones exactly use it .... the idea of starting with junk was an idea i started toying as early as feb 2009 .... 15 minutes (nov 2009) probably uses it. but "rabbit snakes" is really the first time i really used it. (12.25.09) i was just so frustrated with not being able to decide what to do in a song, that i was like, ok .... what's the worst thing that could happen if i just say 'rabbit snakes' like this, right at the top? and then the song bloomed into all kinds of interesting things, including obscure dead-beatle conspiracy references. "dance the" was written probably on the same day, and absolutely starts with garbage, just the same way. "eat bread" also was written at that time, as well as "trees / everything" (this one uses major garbage in the second verse.) "i'm a diamond" (apr 2010) is a very clear example. starting in august 2010, i started writing a LOT more, and used that a lot. that's when i came up with the name for the concept ('murder your demon') and you get songs like 2010, the summertime, pretty much everything from aug 2010 (also recorded at that time). "i like." "modern woes". There are many many many more songs written from 09, 10, .. only a small percentage of them got recorded (it takes much longer to record a song than to write it, and i wrote way too much). in the second half of 2010 i probably wrote more than any other time.... ('dream of evil' came from that time, not sure if that exactly uses 'demon' technique because i don't think any of those parts were specifically deliberately throw-away.) in 2011 i made a big effort to try to write in a more 'normal' way, so there are not any examples from 2011. (well, maybe from early 2011 you have 'skip to my loo'). near the end of 2011 you have 'write a tune that really sucks' that was just a one-off. (also that is an example where instead of going into something non-garbage, it just ends instead. that's an alternate strategy). 2012/13 was all gathering and updating all the existing songs, so not too many new ones got started. but there was one random library session in june 2013 where i wrote several, just like the old days. "tuesday" is the main example (and actually kind of a tutorial on how the technique works)

003902.question: About how long will your this long video you're working on be? I ask because you say you might be finished by christmas and I take everything seriously and also I don't know how far away christmas is but I think it's far off.
003902.answer: my original goal was to make it somewhere between 5 and 10 minutes. writing the script now, and it clocks in at about 5:40 and i JUST got to what is supposed to be the "main topic" of the video. it's like if you are making a video about fruit, and you are 5 minutes into the video and you just got to the part that talks about the fruit. So that tells me that the total length of the video should probably be at least double what i have so far. If i can get it to work in 10min, that would be great. if it goes up to 15 min and stays engaging and interesting all the way through, i think that would be fine. Japan video was 9, and it took 98 days of solid work to finish it, but i was also doing 6 second vines every day for most of that time, which i am now not doing. also i have probably learned some things from experience and perhaps things will move faster. then again, this video might require many new kinds of graphics tricks. i am working as fast as possible, as always

003956.question: this clave is not Nigerian, is it?. and if i'm not mistaken I think it goes like (and it starts on the last A) AaAaAAaAaAaA
003956.answer: the 'clave' or whatever it's really called, has seemed to permeate the globe throughout every time period. but i can confirm, from playing in a nigerian church, that all the up-tempo songs are based rhythmically around 2 rhythms, which seem to correspond nearly exactly with what i have heard through the grape vine to be the so called "clave" rhythms. one in 4/4 using 16th notes (AaaAaaAaaaAaAaaa) and one at the same tempo using triplets instead, and the rhythm is (AaAaaAaAaAaa). they don't have a name for it, but it is always those 2 rhythms

004012.question: what is a nice thing you have learned while editing video?
004012.answer: many things. here's one. The program i'm using doesn't have enough keyboard shortcuts, which is really problematic for working fast. But maybe a year after i had been using it and doing videos every day, i found an insane work around. On a mac, there is a help menu, which seems to have access to EVERY menu command, and it is searchable. So if i type ⌘? and then the first 2 (or 3) letters of the menu command, then hit enter, it works. Sure, it's like 8 keystrokes, but once you get fast at it, it is almost as good as having a key-command. Finding a keyboard shortcut for something that doesn't have a keyboard shortcut is a huge victory if you are trying to make content as fast as humanly possible

004021.question: I understand you are in the writing stage of your next long video. What does your plan look like after that's done? (for example, the first step was probably like research, then writing, etc.)
004021.answer: this progress report (from during the history of japan process) shows the basic breakdown of the steps. even though that was my first time, the process seems very stable, so I plan on doing it the same way. after the writing is done, i will record a temp vocal (with the right timing) and import it into the timeline. also i will record temp versions of all the jingles, and put them in too. (at that point, i will also have a solid estimate of how long it is). the next phase is "prelim graphics collection", which would be finding all the materials i need to download, so in the case of Japan, it would be pictures of emperors and stuff, maps (even if i'm not using the map, i need to find maps that show the proper locations of the things i am mentioning.) A lot of times this means i have to do more research, because if i say "and then they built a palace, right here" ... i now have to dig back into the research and really pinpoint where and when that palace is supposed to be, and find the right picture, etc. This phase also can see a few re-writes happening, because i might notice certain parts are not hitting the way i want, or are possibly impossible to explain graphically

004110.question: WhEn ArE yOu SuPpOsEd To UsE cApItAl LeTtErS
004110.answer: according to the British Royal Crown, you are supposed to capitalize the first letter of every sentence, and also the first word of important things or people, such as the Queen of England, or Harvard University. in my experience, this doesn't really help in communication, and almost hinders it, because you are giving off the impression that you are writing some kind of official document, and possibly not saying what you really mean. The times i prefer to use capitals are in acronyms (like NAFTA, or UNESCO), sometimes at the beginning of sentences if i feel i am changing gear or tone (similar to the way you might use a paragraph break) or also when i want to emphasize one word, i may capitalize the first letter of that word, creating something similar to a bold effect. it is a nice surefire way to emphasize a word even if it is not guaranteed that the 'bold' effect is available, and it is more Mild than the more 'screaming' style of ALL CAPS. then again, when i am trying to convey something of maximum urgency i might possibly use all caps

004148.question: Me and my friend wrote a short film but have no idea how to execute it. We don't have a lot of money to hire actors and such and we can barely afford props but we need to succeed at this film. It is the one thing I'm good at and I can't fail. I am very proud of the script and would really really enjoy doing this.
004148.answer: you are going to have to comprimise. really stretch the limits of what you can act out yourself. then, of all the elements that you feel you "can't" provide yourself, narrow it down to like the most important thing that's missing, and then stretch your available contacts to the limit to find *something* or *someone*. make little comprimises here and there, from re-writes to re-casting, comprimise a little bit everywhere and you will get it done. filmmaking is insane, it requires a small country to do it "right" but there's only one path to get there and it's comprimise. even the big league films make comprimises (for example the viewer is not actually in the film)

004150.question: is it very important to work straight from beginning to end on the new video, or would you consider taking one week to work on a song and music video to release before the long video is done?
004150.answer: well i was doing that for a little bit, but i got such harsh lectures for "not doing a history video" sayind stuff like "bill, why aren't you doing a history video" and "bill, you fucking idiot, why aren't you doing a history video." which makes me so angry because i AM doing a history video. there are 2 things i want to do desperately, and that's songs and research videos. I'm not sure where people stand on this issue. i just can't take being accused of not doing something i AM doing, AND it is something i want to do. i want to do them both, so it is very difficult to see where to go here. in a way, i want to start doing songs every week, like NOW, but at the same time i gotta get this history video done. Even people who defend me say "hey, he only wanted to make history of japan, that was a one-time deal. leave him alone." but it's NOT a one-time deal whatsoever. japan was just a test run of a much greater realm of the research format. So either way i am stuck. it's a lot like how i felt stuck between vine and history, before the history video came out, everyone thought i was an 'idiot' and 'irresponsible' for not following through on more vines. it's hard to figure out who is in the majority, and i don't think i should. i saw a content creator try to do a voting system for what the fans thought he should do, and i was honestly very turned off by the idea. i was thinking "you're the dude, i'm following YOU, ... if you're the leader and you don't know where to go, that's not a very strong sign of leadership." so i generally try to stay away from trying to go strictly where the majority would say i should go. besides, if i did that, there's no way i would have taken the risk to do history of japan when i already had a vibrant vine following. so ultimately i have to do what i think is right, and i am extremely torn between songs and big videos at this juncture, but this particular video is turning out to be really large and epic and i think it is exactly what needs to happen right now. and it could easily take a few more months if i work SOLIDLY on it. who knows what may happen if i try to take detours and do songs.... that will make it take even longer, and imagine how much more intense the lectures will get

004228.question: Dear Sir: I have been requested by the Nigerian National Petroleum Company to contact you for assistance in resolving a matter. The Nigerian National Petroleum Company has recently concluded a large number of contracts for oil exploration in the sub-Sahara region. The contracts have immediately produced moneys equaling US$40,000,000. The Nigerian National Petroleum Company is desirous of oil exploration in other parts of the world, however, because of certain regulations of the Nigerian Government, it is unable to move these funds to another region. You assistance is requested as a non-Nigerian citizen to assist the Nigerian National Petroleum Company, and also the Central Bank of Nigeria, in moving these funds out of Nigeria. If the funds can be transferred to your name, in your United States account, then you can forward the funds as directed by the Nigerian National Petroleum Company. In exchange for your accommodating services, the Nigerian National Petroleum Company would agree to allow you to retain 10%, or US$4 million of this amount. However, to be a legitimate transferee of these moneys according to Nigerian law, you must presently be a depositor of at least US$100,000 in a Nigerian bank which is regulated by the Central Bank of Nigeria. If it will be possible for you to assist us, we would be most grateful. We suggest that you meet with us in person in Lagos, and that during your visit I introduce you to the representatives of the Nigerian National Petroleum Company, as well as with certain officials of the Central Bank of Nigeria. Please call me at your earliest convenience at 18-467-4975. Time is of the essence in this matter; very quickly the Nigerian Government will realize that the Central Bank is maintaining this amount on deposit, and attempt to levy certain depository taxes on it. Yours truly, Prince Alyusi Islassis

004351.question: If the Japan video took about 3 and a half months can we expect similar content to be spaced out by at least this kinda time-interval?
004351.answer: there is a huge range of different types of content that is desperately important. one of them is research videos. if that were the only thing, then that would be all i would do. however, another thing that is equally important to me is recording as many of the 100s of songs i've written as possible, as well as going on many new songwriting adventures. there are other things i am intensely interested in doing also, but songs and research videos are probably at the top right now. that being said, the current research video i am working on will be at least 25% longer than history of japan, and probably 10 times as dense, research wise. i am not saying i enjoy this dire content-to-lifetime ratio, but it is a reality i have been living with for most of my life. i am always making comprimises to try to accomplish as much as possible in my lifetime, in addition to continuing to work steadily every single day

004353.question: how did the video and the song hi it's 1995 came out what was the inspiration for that video
004353.answer: was written sometime in 2013, i was mostly doing revises and edits for existing songs, i don't know why the 1995 one came to me out of nowhere. being short, it reached 100% completion automatically, so it ended up in the 'completed songs' list which formed itself and then was arranged in order of time length, during 2013. and i started recording shortest-first, so naturally 1995 was one of the first ones. also, during 2013 i was trying to get started doing videos for them, which i was ALSO starting with shortest first. 1995 was sort of a stray, i was almost giving up on shortest first, and i had just finished building the website, and this was right before i spontaneously started the 5-day schedule. the concept for the video seemed straight forward. so i brainstormed a list of all the items - there were probably about 20-25 relevant items i came up with and found images for. and then i spent some time figuring out which ones to put where in the 5x3 grid. interestingly enough, a year later when i edited it for vine, i had room for one more item (vines are square, so it became a 4x4 grid, 16 items instead of 15.) so there is actually 1 additional item that got added to the vine edit

004354.question: I really lie your song I'm crazy/It's rining and I want to ask you why that song has two titles?

004355.question: Do you think you'll ever significantly update your musical workflow? If so, what are you looking forward to? Virtual instruments? Kurzweil synths? A banjo?
004355.answer: it will probably take a major global political upheaval to get me off the midi-only method. that being said, i would love to get my hands on some new sounds, HOWEVER i need to always find ways to keep it really simple, because i just collapse if there are too many choices. sometimes i feel like it was easier when i used garageband because there were fewer possibilities

004356.question: You said in a previous answer that you used to write down all your music and only learned to use voice memos/improvised riffs in 2011. I can only write music the second way, and I find it very, very difficult to write music notation-first. Did you learn to write music that way in music school, or is that your "natural" composing style? Do you think it's worth it for me to force myself to write music on paper before touching the keyboard/guitar as a learning experience?
004356.answer: do whatever works. for a long time i was unable to do it the 'memo' way ... because how do you figure out which part to start with? how do you figure out when something is final? all kinds of questions, my mind would fall apart. so eventually i just said, 'well, i have to start somewhere' and i figured i was literate enough to just hit the page and start writing. but this results in a very strange kind of writing (think "modern woes" or "rabbit snakes") where you start with some completely random garbage, and then that part is final. and you have to move on to the next part. so you get this disjointed thing-after-thing format, almost never obeying any repeating form. write however you can. for me it was just a last ditch effort to get something to happen. eventually i finally learned how to organize my world enough to work the other way, and now i have a very solid system of text files and memo files, and everything is catalogued in a way that i know what i'm doing, and i know what i did.

004358.question: What are your fillers/shorts going to be while you make the History of the Universe or whatever it is? Bed sheets? Ceiling fans? Nuclear Powered Wallpaper?

004457.question: i have a specific question, i hope you don't mind answering it. in your world what is your name for this particular chord voicing? starting on D just below middle C and going up D F# G D E? commonly played on guitar. Dadd4add9? D4add9? D24? wtf
004457.answer: well, it's kind of like you have red and blue at the same time. what you call it depends on what's around it. like if the entire canvas is red, and then some parts of it had blue also, you would call those parts the 'blue parts' and not mention the red. but if the entire canvas was blue and red, then you would call all the parts "blue and red." what i'm trying to say is, that chord is full blown D and Dsus2/4 at the same time. but from a song perspective, it is likely that you may alternate that chord with just regular D. if that is the case, like in the all red (and some blue) painting, you would call it D2/4, because that's the part that has D2/4, and the regular D part doesn't. but if you were playing only entirely that chord (with the 2 and 4 and 1 and 3 together) for the whole time, then you might as well say D add this add that add everything including the kitchen sink. Also the reader will have more time to read it if it's the only chord on a page. but if it is in a song where regular D chords are also used, then i would def. just say D2/4 and it's players choice if u wanna open it all up like that

004468.question: i'm trying to transcribe a song but i can't make out the voicing of the last chord. do you have any ideas? https://clyp.it/qlx11xk1
004468.answer: well, the first instinct is that it's a standard 5 chord from Fmin, with all the dirty notes -- mainly including the 'dirtiest' note, Gb. so the melody is on top (c, 2 oct above middle C) then right under it you have Ab in the piano, then E under that, and down in the lower octave you have Gb, and then Db (next to middle C). by 'law' it feels like Bb has to be in this chord, and I am almost certain it is. usually Bb likes to go next to middle C, in that range, for these chords. certainly it is C7, b9, b13, b5 (oh also, no one would be playing a G note, i can guarantee that, there is no room for that, they are already playing all the other notes, plus we just came from a G rooted chord). so that is my best assessment. the note that makes this chord sound extra dirty is the Gb. all the other notes are completely standard for c7 in f minor

004480.question: What was going through your mind when you made 'Help me, I'm trapped in the center of a rectangle'?
004480.answer: i was coming off of a many years long hiatus from recording, and all the midi/sequencing programs i had used before were long gone. but i was ready to start again, and even though i absolutely hated garageband, i finally realized it was time to start, even if that was what i had to use. also i had become much 'experimental' in life since the last time i had recorded music, so i wasn't sure exactly what direction(s) to go. i very spontaneously recorded 4 pieces of music (instrumental, didn't have a mic yet) where i tried to just really thrash around and have fun, and break some rules and see what happened. 'rectangle' was the first of those 4. 'time mop' was the third of those 4, which would years later have a video made for it

004498.question: here's a story. i encountered my friend at the pool. she wasn't holding any children. i was: exactly one child. my friend asked me, who's that? i said, my south-asian child that i birthed. she laughed, and said, no, really. who is it. i said, there's no trick to make me say something else. it's my south-asian child. there are several arts about this story that i would like you to evaluate. [several - 2]. saying something provocative that applies both in character and out of character: this applies to the last item of dialogue. if it is, in fact, my child (or i am ardently trying to project that image) then i am saying, nothing you can say will change the truth. if it is not my child, and i am briefly setting down the notion that it is my child, then i am telling my friend that there is nothing that she can say that will make me break character. isn't that neat? how arty is it, maybe out of 10? [several - 1]. it is clear in this story that there is some armada of reasons that it is unlikely that this is actually my child. the one that is intuitive to me is some race disparityŃafter all, i said that i, specifically, birthed it. however, the reader is left to decide these reasons for herself. is this ambiguity a good thing in storytelling? out of 10 is fine again but numbers are usually different than ideas, and concepts [several]. what do you think about having a different way to process quotes than the next guy? should i sacrifice ease of reading simply for the purpose of, yes, i am definitely reading a different thing than that other thing. thanx!
004498.answer: 2. i don't understand what you are asking 1. i had no problem accepting that it was the narrator's child, there were no race issues. i simply assumed that the narrator was a south-asian woman. there were certain things about the phrasing that sounded peculiar, but that did not de-rail the logic of the story whatsoever 0. i think it is useful to be clear about where the quotes are, but i actually found it very easy to see where the quotes are in this story, and it really didn't bother me 1. i would like to add that i do think this is a good story, and leaves the reader to wonder what the hell is the point of the entire story, and the fact that the questions seem to make even less than the story (despite appearing so earnestly to make sense) adds to the intrigue

004528.question: what is your opinion on composing music using ways? e.g. the passacaglia format where you have a 4-8ish measure bass sequence that repeats for the whole thing. a somewhat popular and recent example is c418's sweden from the minecraft soundtrack. to me, with this sort of thing, there's two potential appeals: shock value (omg! a passacaglia) and innovation (using an arbitraryish restriction can improve both your own thing and the restriction) but both of these can easily work against you. there has been at least one time where i have lied.
004528.answer: i have tried using loop based writing, based on the fact that looped stuff has been used so heavily in the last ... 30 years. but ultimately i realized that given my particular strengths, it is best to not confine myself to loops, but rather to just write what i want to write when i want to write it

004564.question: Did you ever find what you were looking for in New Canaan? And how do you throw in a bridge section effectively after a few verses? "You can do whatever you want to" has a smooth harmonic transition from verse to bridge and back to verse.
004564.answer: it should be looked at like a medical diagnosis. each song is different. never try to do the exact same thing that worked on another song. each song might want something differently. including no bridge, another verse, a pineapple, or just ending the song right there. be aware of the songs's specific needs

004636.question: what are advantages to playing 5-string bass instead of a 4-string bass, and should i throw my 5-string bass away? or sell it
004636.answer: the advantages are the low notes between B and E. you can certainly live without B, but if you really have to live without that Eb, you could find yourself in some sad situations. however, if you are clever, you can learn to survive just fine. after all, everyone got along just fine until the 1980s. personally, i use at least down to Db quite frequently. In modern times, i have found that many players use an octave doubler (with a 4 string) when they need those notes. however, some players choose to use the octave doubler irresponsibly, and they go way below B, resulting in a rumbly mess, and also being punched in the face by me

004668.question: i always come up with the chorus first, but have trouble writing verses that don't sound like a completely song. is there a strategy to overcome this?
004668.answer: i have been searching for a good strategy for this for a long time, and before 2011 i really had no idea how to do it at all. in fact, here is me struggling with this exact situation. that is why pretty much every song i wrote before that point was just a chain from beginning to end, (like this) that just rambles from section to section, with no guarantee of ever settling into a form. eventually after studying and analyzing hundreds of songs, i finally sort of loosely came up with some concepts for thinking about some of the different types of forms that songs can have, and nowadays i am able to use a process-of-elimination strategy. to this day, 'writing something to go before something that is already written' remains a huge challenge, but if i really focus on the issues at hand, i am usually able to find solutions

004681.question: Why do the key changes at the prechoruses of "we could just get high" not follow a pattern? (D to A, D to C#, G# to Bb)
004681.answer: why would they follow a pattern? the human listener notices how it feels, not how it looks when you analyze it on paper. it's kind of like how stories have twists and turns and surprises. Actually, i was stumped on this song for months -- i had verse 1, cho, verse 2, and just was losing momentum in the second chorus --- that was before i had the idea for the second key change. then all of a sudden it occured to me to put the second chorus in a much different key, and that really sparked the right feeling at that point in the song. The first chorus already sort of had that effect (raised a whole step), and it was a natural continuation of the 'liberating/escape' feeling to have the second chorus be unexpectedly even more adventurous. From that point on, it was just a delicate balance of where i thought it should go next, and i just listened carefully to where it wanted to go from there, and the song was finished very quickly

I don't mean to come off as entitled, I just sincerely wonder what the trepidation is about.

004850.question: you said "i really wanna do a band" and have expressed interest in playing live and possibly touring. can you explain why you want to? or how it would be more fun or fulfilling than what you are doing now?
004850.answer: wow, isn't it obvious? usually the questions go the other way around, and i usually have to defend the fact that i do everything myself. live playing in a band is where the real musical paradise is, i just always felt unlucky enough that i grew up in a sort of social isolation, and combined with personality factors, just ended up alone and never able to find the right people. i always figured the light at the end of the tunnel would be eventually having enough influence and/or money that i could do have a medium/large band to actually direct, and afford to pay great people and really do it right

004851.question: I noticed your songs page doesn't have every single jingle in MP3 format. Do the missing ones only exist as videos?
004851.answer: it has always been confusing to draw the line for what to include on that page. it used to include only things that were written first as songs. then as there were more and more 'musical' vines, i felt it was unfair to not include some of those. so i ended up adding many of the musical vines, but still not including ones that rely on the video (how am i gonna include a "how to fly a plane" jingle, outside the context of explaining the answer?) as it is, it feels like there are way way too many short bits on the songs page, and that is compounded by the fact that i recorded a way too high percentage of short songs even before i started doing videos. this balance will hopefully finally be corrected soon when i start recording songs weekly or bi-weekly (WITHOUT also trying to do short vids every day like in 2014)

004852.question: In your 'end of the world concert' song, do you know that song as 'On the Floor' or as 'Lambada'?
004852.answer: it was inspired by the j-lo version (actually only the epic spiritual instrumental riff part of the song, not the generic saturday night drunk america part). i do realize that the melody is based on an ancient traditional song that has gone around the block numerous times throughout the ages, and i have heard those as well. but at the time i was playing the 2011, as is evident in the chords. this caused a bit of a mental dilema when posting it to the site, because i wanted to link the 'info' button to the most authentic and original version of the song, but the bottom line is, the chords for the original version are different. i was playing the chords for the j-lo version. so that is why i chose to link the info to the j-lo version. but really what i was referencing was only the riff portion of the j-lo version

005107.question: I write music for fun and post it online or whenever I feel like it and have the time. I haven't released much, but the ones I have released I've put a ton of time and effort into. I've gotten a few offers from indie game developers, but always ended up declining due to confidence issues and so composers much younger than me end up getting the job instead. I'll listen to their final product and notice how generic it sounds or how I'm sure I could do better, but when I'm given the opportunity to do it I run away. What is wrong with me?
005107.answer: the reason those "other" composers sound "generic" is because they are doing it as a job. a paid gig. if you are putting a lot of time and effort and care into what you are doing, then a paid situation is only going to drive you crazy. sure, there are 'paid' gigs for people who really care, but they pay WAY more, and you only get those gigs when you reach a more steven spielberg kind of level. these kids who are taking your gigs are working for cheap, and they don't care, and they don't have to care, because they are working for people who can't afford to pay them to care. real care is worth much, much, more than that. in fact, it's priceless. if you care, you need to take a very different approach, and find something else to do for work, and devote your true 'care' to what you really care about. in other words, if you try to sell your babies, you will only be undercut by somebody making cheaper and dumber babies. and that will be so uninspiring that it will ruin your day

What do you expect the reactions would be towards pushed legislation, and how would such arguments regarding rights and freedoms hold up against the possible detriments of reaching a point where food, water, and other resources are inadequate to support the people, leading into collapse of organized society, or government enforced regulation of food supplies and distribution? Is the forementioned distopia-like situation a ridiculous extreme? Would people be willing to accept the concept of a country stagnant in population growth over the personal shock of being limited to only on e or two children? 005375.question: Hey man. I really appreciate your work, and the way you're documenting so much of your process and putting it out there. I discovered your website tonight. I've learnt a lot from reading many of your answers on this page. Thank you for that. I get the recurring uneasy feeling that I need to Create Art that I need to produce something beautiful with my own hands. But I am too busy consuming things instead. There are too many books to read, songs to discover, plays/films to watch. So much to learn. And such little time. Also the stupid but inescapable notion that nothing I create will be Good Enough, and other silly reasons that I keep putting it off like the decision about which tools to focus on becoming better at playing around with first. Words? Musical instruments? Cameras? I want to do it all but also sometimes I don't want to do anything. How does one consume less and create more?
005375.answer: just keep being undecided until you can't take it anymore. that sounds like a terrible strategy but it worked for me

005501.question: Imaj6/9 VIIb6add4 IV VImaj9 I'm struggling to think of a fun extension for the IV chord in this progression. What would you suggest? VIIb6/9 - Imin(add9) - VIbmaj9 This is the progression for the next section. Why does the Imin work as well as the Imaj?
005501.answer: you are not giving me enough details for me to understand the context of this. to be fair, in my opinion the only way to really know how music goes is to hear it. all those chords could be voiced in a million different ways, and more important still is the timing. also, what the heck is VIIb6? don't you mean bVII6? also, i use chords as a way to support the song. i am usually not interested in evaluating chords outside of the context of the song. and if so, i would definitely need more specifics as to exactly how each one is voiced, in which octave, and more importantly the timing, tempo, etc. none of which can be determined by looking at a list of chords

005507.question: This is similar to the job question that was asked earlier - but forgive me, it may be lengthy. Let's say you've been with a company for 1 month, and someone else was also hired at the same time as you, with a similar role. The other person learned the job quicker than you, and everyone in the department seems to love that person but not you. You feel it's partly because you took longer to learn and asked a lot more questions than the other person, and now your entire department basically doesn't treat you well. Even though now you are fairly confident with your responsibilities and have been doing good work. Should you stay, or pursue a job with a better "crowd" of people? I feel like this department I'm with involves a complete clash of personalities between me and them. Also important to note: This job is what I went to school for and pays very well. But I feel so shut out from my department that I'm basically desiring a customer s ervice j ob now, like I used to do. Help!!!

005579.question: That question about a440 made me curious about an aspect of having perfect pitch (which I do not have) When I hear a note that is sharp or flat relative to its accompaniment it makes me feel very uncomfortable. I find myself straining as though I could correct the pitch with my thoughts alone -- much in the same way I might lean to one side to try to influence an errant bowling ball after it has left my hand. Do you ever get this feeling? If so, does it only occur for you when the tone is out of tune relative to the musical context? Or, having perfect pitch, does it also happen for you if the music is in tune with itself, but not with the traditional a440 tuning?
005579.answer: anyone who claims to be 'irritated' when a recording is fully in tune with itself, but not tuned to a440, is faking it. this is not irritating, it's just a way to brag about having perfect pitch. even worse, many people who do this are actually wrong about it-- they will tell you the radio is out of tune because they speed up the songs to get more ads in, but that is not true anymore, now they can speed up the songs without changing the pitch, so everything you hear on the radio is in a440, for the most part

005613.question: what is the voicing of the first 'oldies' chord in this clip? https://instaud.io/vqE
005613.answer: OL = bass C, melody very strongly high Eb. harmonizing in the middle we have Ab, Eb, and i think very likely and subtlely there is a E note. also Bb underneath that. (so that makes it C+7#9). and for DIES, i am hearing more of a straight C7, including E, and G. (and still Bb) and i also am feeling the presence still of Eb (or maybe even Db) dirtying it up just a bit, which would mean either C7#9 or C7b9, but the presence of that note is extremely subtle (as well it should be) and might possibly just be the reverb ringing over from the previous chord. so OL is Caug7#9 and 'dies' is C7 with possible very subtle #9. the melody and bass notes are much stronger than the harmony notes, as they should be

005695.question: recommendations for a beginners keyboard?
005695.answer: the only thing that matters is whether it can tell the difference between a loud and soft note. test it by hitting it hard and see if the note is louder than when you hit it soft. get a keyboard as cheap as you want, but make sure it has this otherwise your whole life will be ruined. (some of the cheap ones don't have it). it is called 'dynamic sensitivity' and if a keyboard doesn't have it, even a perfectly good player will mysteriously sound like a toddler. it's not even fair. it would be like having only one volume for your voice-- you go to whisper in someone's ear, it comes out normal speaking volume. you are being attacked by wolves and you cry for help, and it comes out in a normal speaking volume. this would cripple your ability to express yourself, and the same thing would happen if you had a keyboard without dynamic sensitivity. don't make that mistake. again, you don't have to get an expensive keyboard, you just need to test it to make sure loud and soft notes are a thing

005720.question: how quickly can you tell what note is being sung? are you calculating it's interval from a reference note you know very well in your head or do you just know exactly what the note is the moment you hear it?
005720.answer: my relative skills vastly overshadow the absolute. i was not trained to care about the absolute from a young age, but as a result of learning everything in C, i do actually have C built in. it is a strange paradox, and in the last several years i have started to feel entitled to having the absolute, knowing that it must be possible due to the overwhelming reality of accurate song and sound memory. so i have over the years strengthened the framework to the point where overall i can pretty much claim to have the absolute, at least as well as anyone else who makes that claim. and the relative remains lightening fast, and is further strengthened by some of the absolute strategies i have. it is important to remember that the absolute is not an important musical skill

005953.question: What do you do when you don't know how the next part of a song should go?
005953.answer: clear your mind, and do accurate, timed run throughs! i usually do it with a click. and if i really get stuck, i do a 'door touch' to try to re-set my mind. i walk over to the door and touch the door knob and walk back to my seat and then play the song, all the way through. the more you can re-set your mind, the more accurate picture you will have of the song after doing a full run through. after doing an accurate timed run through, you will start to get a vision of an answer somewhere within the last few seconds of the known song, and it may linger within the first few seconds after you stop. it will start to fade after that. the whole secret is to pay very very close attention in this moment, and try to gather as much info as possible about the situation, (of course you might get lucky and lightening might strike and you might find the whole solution instantly) but try to play process of elimination -- sometimes you might find out you 'definitely don't want another chorus' or you 'definitely want something with the same chords' or you 'definitely want something different' or you 'definitely want something the same' .... try to listen to as many clues as you can find, to narrow it down, ... and then clear your mind and do another run through. don't forget that if you already have 'critical mass' in the song, you are never obligated to do anything more, the only thing you are obligated to do is 'carry the song home', which might even mean ending it sooner than you thought. or it might mean repeating what you have. or it might mean doing something totally different. it's important to stay very open, and again, the only thing that will really produce a reliable solution is clearing your mind, and an accurate, timed run through, and paying very close attention to the moment when you reach the end of the known material. i hope that helps

005954.question: How important is it to finish songs when you have no idea what you are doing?
005954.answer: it is very important. the reason is: uncertainty can and will strike at any time. songwriting is such an open game, and anything can happen. if you start getting the idea that it is ok to give up, you will probably never get anywhere. the crazy tricks you will invent to overcome uncertainty are what is going to give your songs character. if you are afraid to think like that, then you are not even in the game

006018.question: it seems like humans tend to organize numbers in 10s because we have 10 fingers. any thoughts why rhythmic beats are usually grouped in 4s?

Besides powers of 2, the next number that seems to play by far the most significant role in rhythms, melodies, (and our minds in general!) is 3. 006094.question: So I got access to many professional Big Band charts. I play to them on drums, but I think it would be cool to play to them on my keyboard. I know all the basics of a keyboard, because I'm a percussionist, and I know this will sound stupid, but what's Fm7 or Bb7 mean and how the Fuck do you play them. I believe they're chords, but what's the 7 mean??
006094.answer: play the Ab note just below middle C, and also the Eb right above middle C. then play the F that is 2 and a half octaves below middle C. that is the Fmin7 chord. now for the other chord, keep all the notes the same but for the bass note, play Bb instead of F, and that high Eb move it down to D. that is how you play those 2 chords, in the context you are referring to

006144.question: Hi Bill, I would like to talk to you concerning your "history of japan" video. Why have you glossed over the atrocities Japan has committed, which are major events in Japan's history? Examples include the Rape of Nanking, the South Korean Comfort Women, and the human testing conducted on Chinese civilians. These are important issues that cannot be forgotten. However, they are not present at all in your video, which has been viewed over 16 million times. This is encouraging the ignorance of the "darker side" of Japan's history. While countries such as Germany have deeply apologized for their war atrocities and engrain these events in teaching history to their students, the Japanese government has refused to apologize and Japanese textbooks are being revised to omit these events. I sincerely believe that you are a very learned and good person, thus I hope that you are aware of this and that with your large following and outreach, I hope that you may also raise awareness of this issue. Japan's war atrocities are not to be glossed over.

006213.question: What is your percentage of honesty while answering these questions?

006236.question: Why do some keys sharpen "E" and flatten "C" when both of those notes are just "F" and "B". Particularly since those notes don't have an actual sharp or flat? Why kind of bullshit is that?
006236.answer: it's really just to make it work on the staff, because a key signature has to set you up so you have 1 of each letter. otherwise the key of F# would have 2 F's at the same time (F and F#) or the key of Gb (same key actually) would have 2 B's (B and Bb) and it would be a disaster on the staff, you would have to keep flattening and unflattening the B even just to write like a normal Gb major melody. it's really just to make the scale work with all the letters in a row. that's the point of key signatures. it's like 7 people with names A thru G have to represent the scale by holding up sharp/flat signs (or no sign). if you were not allowed to use E#, then the only way to make the key of F# would be to clone Frannie and kill Eddie

006981.question: what progress have you made on the video today?
006981.answer: today had some very intense setbacks and yet very intense progress. lately as i've shifted into the beginning stages of production (from writing) the looming magnitude of this project has intensified even more, which is hard to even imagine considering it was already unimaginably intense (the research and writing actually took 12 weeks.) there are endless new challenges, and i saw some particularly technical ones today, relating to processing power, etc. i will need to make small comprimises across the board in order to do anything at a respectable pace. that's about all i can say without going into detail. on the other hand, i had some victories content wise, regarding re-writes and trims. at what is now 5:56, this point was at 7:15 in the first draft. this is good news because i was concerned that the original 22 min draft not only had some tedious and tiresome parts, but it is also not reasonable to ever expect to finish the video if it is that long. getting into the swing of these re-writes, the prospect looks good for actually bringing this endlessly long thing down to a still-very-long but very swift and exciting adventure, and also be feasibly finishable by the end of the decade

007171.question: In your song New Canaan, you say that you're going to New Canaan, Pennsylvania, then later rectify that the town is actually in Connecticut (which is true). However, you go on to refer to it as "New Canaan, Pennsylvania" many times after that. Why?
007171.answer: not many times, only once. and there are multiple reasons why. the first reason would be the same reason that it is said that way in the first line of the song -- it is just better melodically. the second reason is because given that it already is that way at the beginning of the verse, the verse naturally wants to end the same as it started. and the 3rd reason it makes sense is that by immediately returning to false details after having explained the real truth, we have now firmly established the recurring theme of incorrect details, which is further developed later. i think if you try singing 'connecticut' in either of the first 2 locations where it's 'pennsylvania' i think you will find that it is not only extremely awkward, but also undermines one of the main concepts of the song

007369.question: When you say you've edited parts of the video, are you editing the script first before moving on, or are you working on the video and saying "this portion of the script should be trimmed"?
007369.answer: i'm on 'phase 2' or the 'plan' stage, or 'pre-graphics', i am not sure what to call it. a lot of the graphic work actually gets done during this stage, it's basically like figuring out how the hell i am actually going to display on the screen what i just said in the script, and it actually inolves doing a lot more research, like nailing down exact geography specifics so i can show them on the map, or finding the images of people, etc etc. Like if i said "and then the clowns took over" ... a picture is worth a thousand words, so that may be fine for the script, but in order to show it on screen i have to know which clowns, i have to know what they were supposed to look like, i have to know exactly where they took over, so that often involves doing more research. or if i say 'then cheese wiz was invented' ... which cheese wiz was the first cheeze wiz? i can't just show modern cheese wiz and pass that off for the first kind. and a lot of times during this stage i may realize that a certain line in the script actually won't work, either because i realize it is innacurate, or maybe just doesn't seem good enough. so little revisions happen during this stage. also as i mentioned, the first draft was way longer than i wanted it to be, so when i do the re-writes i am always trying to say stuff quicker, and so far it is going great. every adjustment i have made has made it stronger and shorter at the same time. the shortening rate is averaging 18%, and i am at about the halfway point of the video

007439.question: Why do you balk at classifying things? Do you not see the traits and methods of execution that cause things to be similar enough to be considered "in a genre"?
007439.answer: you can classify anything, in any way, for any reason. that's part of the fun. there are infinite categories, and you can make up the categories. and they are ever-changing. the lines will always blur, rightfully so. in fact it seems to me that it's hard to really do anything inspiring unless you are blurring someone's line, somewhere. genre naming is (and should be) way way too fluid and elastic for me to ever be able to feel comfortable with a question like 'what genre do you prefer.' to me, favorite-genre questions actually feel the same as 'what race of people do you prefer.' it just seems to crush the entire spirit of life when you look at it that way. i hope that makes sense

007453.question: When you record as the Bill Wurtz Fake Jazz Ensemble, do you always record your tracks in the same order (for instance keyboards first, then drums, etc.)? If so, what is the order? If not, why not?
007453.answer: the whole thing started as a reading exercise, and originally it was usually just whole notes on the chords, and then the melody, sometimes even without drums or anything. but later on i started doing more like a 4 piece arrangement, and mostly now it goes percussion first, (then possibly another track of bigger drums, like kick/snare etc) then chords, then bass, then lead. i know you might think the bass should go before the chords, but nowadays i always do the bass after the chords, for some reason it works better that way. drums always first, but actually percussion before drums, which might seem backwards, but i discovered that percussion before drums actually works better for some reason

007465.question: this morning I was feeling pretty shitty about everything, but then I got a good grade on a test and felt better. but THEN, after another hour, I started to feel shitty again because the only thing that had cheered me up was a number that somebody stamped on my level of understanding of a concept. (does that make sense?) I feel that way a lot when I'm making music - like I shouldn't care what people think and that I should just do what I know feels right, but then crippled when the things I make aren't liked OR affirmed when they are. you're in an interesting position because you claim not to give a shit (which I honestly believe is true) but people still love your work and tell you that all the time. you make whatever you want, but "whatever you want" wins awards. what should I do? how do I ignore them? or how do I balance these two contradictory parts of my brain? OR how do I succeed at making things and feeling like they matter even if they aren't accessible or liked?
007465.answer: you will have to believe in yourself so much that you are willing to start doing things how you want, forever, without waiting for anyone to notice, ever. you really have to be crazy. but the longer you do it, the more real it gets

007552.question: do you ever miss how peaceful it was before the popularity of history of japan
007552.answer: before that video came out i was working my ass off to keep doing 7 new vines a week, due to their popularity. then out of desperation to make a long video, i started doing the vines even faster, to have time to work on a long video at the same time, and i continued on like that for 2 months, and then finally left vine behind in order to do a mad month-long push to get the japan video done, working day and night, while people kept asking why i had 'stopped' making videos. which actually reminds me a lot of how things are going now

007553.question: When you were working hard making 7 new Vines a week and then you started doing them even at a faster pace, do you have some regrets about it, do you feel some videos felt rushed or that quality suffered from the high production and output rate ?
007553.answer: actually no. being forced to work fast is actually a huge blessing. creativity is so flexible, it is amazing the kind of decisions that you make when you have a deadline-- corners you cut, that you never would have dreamed of cutting if u had no deadline, but under pressure you make crazy decisions and your mind instantly gravitates toward the fast choices, and it also encourages you to gravitate toward more exciting choices to make up for the fact that you can't care delicately for every little thing. an example of one of my most intense time-crunches would be the babies-grownups-babies video. i took so many short cuts, and i was just throwing things in there so fast, and I was almost late for work (i am not telling you what my job is) but in the end, no one is complaining and look at all the stuff i have gotten done. given the demonic flexibility of the creative process, i am really feeling like i never want to work off-deadline again. i mean, I have been working off deadline on this current video for more than 4 months, and i THINK i'm going as fast as i can, but at the same time the video is much less than half done and i still have barely even gotten to the production. this is no way to live. i have a lot of stuff to do, songs, videos, so many things left to do and the years are going to fly by if i don't set some more insane deadlines. which is why i have recently set a deadline for the current video, which is completely unreasonable, and yet it is the best thing that has ever happened to me because it is making me get back into serious mad-crunch mode, which brings a much needed thrill to the never ending landscape of uncertainty of when this thing will ever be done

007594.question: How many phases are there in the production of your history video?
007594.answer: it is hard to count them exactly because some of them are less defined than others. but for the history of japan project, it was writing (9 days), 'phase 2' (prelim graphics and writing adjustments if needed) (21 days), temp narr and jingles (maybe 1 day), actual graphics (30 days), then like 1 day of trouble shooting, actual narration (maybe 5 days?), actual jingles (maybe 3 days?) re-allignment of the entire video to fit the final narration (maybe 1 or 2 days), score (about 20 days), label adding (maybe 2 days), final trouble shooting (maybe 2 days). i am not sure of those exact time lengths, but that was about how it worked out. this video should follow a very much identical process, except this video is longer, and also crazier in many ways

007746.question: You might be asked like thirty times before you write a response but in case you haven't, Vine had just announced that they are discontinuing their service in the coming months. They'll keep old videos online. I remember back before History of Japan you were kinda in a love-hate relationship with Vine because it allowed you to trim and really concentrate your content, but doing so was kinda addicting(?) in a way and it sorta stagnated you from making longer videos until you made the bold move to cut Vine off entirely during HoJ production. I'm sorry if this question seems to be spiraling out of control or maybe I'm just rambling, but I'm curious to understand why Vine was an appealing outlet for your content at the time and if you've "grown out" of it and don't mind the discontinuation too much or if you still have some fondness for that service. Thanks for reading, regardless!
007746.answer: i was already making short videos (because it was a good way to get used to making videos), and about a year into it i found out there was a popular platform where the videos were supposed to be short, and they are auto-looped. so it seemed like a good decision to try to get the videos onto there. by the time i actually got most of them on there i was really getting ready to get Off the 5-day schedule and start looking at longer stuff. but then the popularity kicked in on vine (but still not so much on yt because vine doesn't let you put links to anywhere!!), so i had to do more short ones, just when i was really ready to do longer ones. so i had to sort of bend over backwards to condense the 7 day vine production down to as quick as possible to have enough time to try some long stuff, and after 3 months i finally finished one which actually did very well, and within a couple weeks i was doing better outside of vine than on vine. so by that point, not only have i made 200 more short videos than i ever really intended to, now i have a whole new audience which actually gets mad at me for doing short videos. so that's 2 reasons it's time to shift. don't get me wrong, i will still do things of all lengths and types. the original reason i did short things is because i like to do things of all different lengths, and i always wrote things of all different lengths, but the short ones are the quickest to produce, so i always fell into the trap of producing the short ones first, early on, because it is really the only way to get started

007789.question: Looking back at the description of the Japan video, you said there was 1 day on temp narration and then on to the graphics, and then jingles. Just so I'm clear, are you currently on graphics?
007789.answer: that's not quite what it was, but i am still not on the real 'graphics' phase. the current phase i'm still on (and will hopefully be done with in about 12 more hours!!) is kind of like a pre-graphics phase. call it 'pictures', call it 'image collection', call it 'graphics planning', call it 'phase 2', i can't figure out what to call it, and it doesn't really matter. but it involves taking what the words are, and then figuring out what exactly i am going to put in the graphics. like what am i gonna put on screen if i said *this.* a picture is worth a thousand words so it takes longer than you think. plus accuracy is really important. if an i say an earth quake happened in russia, i'm not just going to throw the earth quake in the middle of russia, i need to put it right where it actually happened. so phase 2 deals with all that stuff. including occasional re-writes, as i sometimes will realize that something in the script may be wrong or not work, and have to change it. all the re-writes are rock solid now, and another part of phase 2 is also done (which i can't really talk about right now, and is heavily related to graphics) and now i'm just finishing with pictures, at the 14 min mark as of today, moving roughly a second per minute (which is way up from before, i am setting timers every hour to track my progress and always find new techniques to really push it to the limit) but i will definitely be done with phase 2 like tomorrow. then i will lay down a temp narration for timing, and do temps for all the jingles, and put them in place so i have something to work over, and then do the real actual graphics, which will be what the video actually looks like. that took 30 days for history of japan, but this video is twice as long. the remaining tasks after that also took a total of 30 more days for history of japan, and again this video is twice as long. however, i have set a deadline for the entire video, which is approximately 33 days from now. as you can see there is a huge discrepancy from reality here. but that is how this needs to be approached. the deadline is causing me to think differently, and it is thrilling, and will at least cut the remaining production time in half, even if not the required 1/4x that would be needed to meet the deadline which is surely impossible but as i said i am still taking it seriously, i hope that answers your question

007871.answer: the scale is supposed to use all the letters. so in the key of D, you use the F# note instead of calling it Gb because otherwise there would be 2 G's and no F's. this theory is simple when playing with keys close to the center of the circle, and when playing simple music that mainly stays in scale. if the music gets crazier, it starts to matter less. and as you get to keys close to no-mans-land (6 flats or sharps) the rules also start to break down, and matter less, kind of like calculating time differences between new zealand and hawaii

008143.question: If the video is not finished by your deadline will you continue to work on it?
008143.answer: of course. the deadline was deliberately set to be way sooner than reasonable, and it has always been technically impossible. but the crazy thing is, it has gotten way more possible since i have set it. having that deadline has caused serious miracles to happen. setting time clocks constantly for the entire day, tracking my progress, pushing every minute of every day to the absolute max. and i think it actually makes the video better, because it forces you to make stronger decisions to cope with less time doing tedious nitpicking. the deadline still remains impossible, but i continue to take it seriously, because it is actually becoming more possible. it is so revitalizing to work like this, i think i am never going to work off-deadline again, on anything

008188.question: What are you gonna do if you get to Dec 1st and the video isn't done? Will you set a new, even more ridiculous deadline?
008188.answer: setting a more ridiculous deadline would be hard, because it would have to be in the past at that point. but i will re negotiate, and play it just as tight. the great news is, having this deadline in effect (which it has been since about mid october) has probably reduced the *actual* production time by as much as 2 months. i mean, in october i was potentially looking at what could have been a years worth of work, if i tried to do a slow, careful, thoughtful job. but after setting the dec 1 deadline and slamming through the past 4 weeks on insano mode, it is now almost guaranteed that it will be done by jan 1, but only if i keep taking dec 1 seriously. i am still taking it seriously. aiming to have the graphics done by this thursday, which would mean i have to double my speed from last week, which was already doubled from the speed i was working on the history of japan graphics

008206.question: So with the Dec. 1 deadline, would you say your progress (both for the video and compared to the Japan video) is increasing exponentially?
008206.answer: it increased a lot after oct 15, which is when i established the dec1 deadline, but since then i have pretty much maxed out. i am still setting timers and making minute by minute goals which are attempting to push it tigher, 1min20 seconds (on graphics) per day is about the most i think is possible, that's my grand record, on a full day. but i am still trying to beat that. in order to meet dec1, i pretty much have to be done with the graphics by this thursday (which would entail doing about 4min per day at this point) and even if i did that, i would still have to absolutely crush the rest, at unprecedented levels. still have to record the final narration, and final vocals for all jingles (which mostly has dense 4 part harmonies, as you know. and there's 66 jingles) and do the score, which probably takes the longest out of those 3 things. very important, i wish i could let you hear what history of japan sounded like with only narration and jingles and no underscored music (it is very boring, the underscore has huge effect on the video, that's why i underscore all my own music, moment by moment). Everything after graphics (score, jingles, narration, labels, troubleshoot, etc etc) for history of japan took a total of 30 days. so even if i finish graphics by thursday (wildly impossible) i would have to complete what was 30 days (for a 9 min vid) in 13 days (for a 19 min vid.) so basically that would require more than a 4x speed improvement from what i was doing in dec/jan last year on japan. but, graphics so far has generally been running at 2x speed from last year. i don't know how that's possible. maybe because i'm not trying to make vines every day? not really sure how to account for it, but i guess i have more experience now

008742.question: how do you feel about pirating music? Not yours but in general
008742.answer: copies are not really worth anything. anyone can make a copy of a file on a computer, and share it with a friend. this is free. the only copy of a song that you can really charge for is the original, because if the artist doesn't release the original, then no one will ever hear it. so the original really has the highest value, and the creator can charge any price for it, and if that price is not paid then the song will never be released. but once it is released, it would be hard to sell copies, because anyone can make a copy for free. so any company that is trying to sell you copies of a song (basically any copy after the original) really cannot expect to make money. unless they have some kind of police force to stop people from sharing files with their friends

008797.question: okay, I can recognise beats. what's the next step?
008797.answer: most music uses beats in groups of 4. (1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4, etc). listen to some songs and find the beat like you did before, but instead of counting them all the same, see if you can count them in groups of 4, and see if you can easily find where the "1" is. these groups of 4 are called Measures (or more commonly called "Bars"). every 4 beats (1, 2, 3, 4) makes up a bar. a bar is a unit of time which is 4 beats long. Most songs use 4 beats per bar. some songs use 3 (or even other numbers in rare cases) but usually 4. See if you can find the beats and bars in some of your favorite songs. then the next step is to get some staff paper and i will tell you how rhythms work. actually you can do rhythms without staff paper but if you want to learn to read you are going to eventually have to get staff paper. ok let me know when you are ready for the next step

008820.question: I've got my stave paper. now what? thanks for the info and the time you've put into the answer. it's greatly appreciated
008820.answer: ok, so let's make some empty bars (measures.) draw some vertical lines through the staff like this. those are called bar lines. they separate the bars (measures.) it's like walls, separating the rooms. in my example i have made 8 bars (or 8 measures). each bar will have notes, etc, in it. each bar will have 4 beats worth of music in it (as i mentioned before, most music uses 4 beats per bar. in some cases 3, or even weirder numbers, but most music uses 4). let me know when you are ready to start putting notes, etc, in the bars. just to be clear, the notes will go in between the vertical lines you just drew, and they will go amongst the horizontal lines, occasionally popping out above or below the stack of horizontal lines. the vertical lines are to divide one bar from the next. ok let me know when you are cool with this

008863.question: okay, I've got my staves and bars. now what?
008863.answer: put notes in the bars. let's start with a "quarter note." you can search online for what it looks like. we're not doing pitches right now, just rhythms. so it doesn't matter which line/space you put it on. just put 4 of them in the bar. a quarter note is 1 beat's worth. so if you put 4 quarter notes in each bar, that is basically like when we were counting beats before, except you are playing a note on every beat. if you search online you can probably find an image of exactly what 4 quarter notes in a bar looks like. if you can't figure out how to get your quarter notes looking right, i might be able to scrape together an image, but if you search for an image of 4 quarter notes you should see what this looks like. it is called quarter notes because it is 1 quarter of a bar. in another world, it might also be called a "single note" because it is one BEAT. that would be in a world where the notes where named based on beats. but they are not. in our world, (earth, etc) they are named according to how much of a bar they take up. (assuming your music has 4 beats in a bar, which most music does.) quarter notes. worth 1 beat. 4 can fit in an ordinary bar. put 4 quarter notes in the first bar. now go download a metronome and i will tell you the next step

008893.question: I've got a metronome and I've put the quarter notes (crotchets where I'm from) in the bar. I'm already familiar with some of the other notes like quavers (eighth), minims (half) and semibreves (whole). now what? thanks again
008893.answer: ok great. I will assume you know what all of those notes should look like. you pretty much mentioned all the important ones, except for sixteenth notes, which of course are twice as fast as eighth notes. there are some beaming rules for 8th notes and 16th notes, but first i want to make sure you know your 'rests.' a rest is a space where you don't play any note. it is a place holder, to let the time go by, and not play a note. there are all the same kinds of rests as there are notes (rhythm wise). quarter note rest (takes up one beat, or one quarter of the bar), eighth rest, 16th rest, half rest, whole rest. make sure you are familiar with all these. if you image-search any of those online you should see them instantly. So now in your second bar, put 2 quarter notes, then a quarter rest, then another quarter note. we are reading left to right here by the way. and the quarter notes and quarter rests should all be basically the same distance apart. now you can set your metronome (set it to about 70 bpm i guess) and then when you are ready to start, read what you wrote, by clapping. your instrument is a clap. clap when there is a note, don't clap when there is a rest. start whenever you are ready, but what it should sound like is you will be clapping on all the clicks for 6 clicks in a row, then a click with no clap, and then clap on the 8th click. that is what it would sound like if you clapped out what you have written. let me know if this makes sense. if you are confused i might be able to scrape together an image of what you should have written so far.

009083.question: okay i worked out clapped the bingo rhythm what's next? thanks agian
009083.answer: make a bar full of 8th notes. there will be 8 8th notes per bar. they are usually beamed in groups of 4. so it's almost like making 8 quarter notes, and then draw a line across the top, connecting the stems of the first 4, and then draw another line connecting the stems of the second 4. (look up 'four 8th notes beamed' on google image search, you will probably find what this looks like. or just look up 8th notes beaming. When an 8th note is by itself it uses a flag, but when it is in a group like in our example, it uses beams.) So now you should have a bar full of 8th notes. 8th notes are worth half a beat, or 1 eighth of a bar. if you clap out this rhythm, the claps will be evenly spaced, and there will be 2 claps per beat. in other words you will be clapping twice as fast as the click. If your tempo (speed) is 70bpm, then you can actually get a sneak preview of what this will sound like, if you set your metronome to 140. the 140 click would be what 8th notes would sound like at 70bpm. now set the click back to 70 and try clapping out the 8th notes at 70. i hope this makes sense

009101.question: it's a bit annoying that people are imitating me and saying that they've done the next musical step. I have done what you said (beamed quavers etc) anyway. obviously these questions are open to the public (rightfully so) so anyone can gain from your answers. just a bit lame that they even try to copy my writing style haha. thanks for all the help so far
009101.answer: i am sorry about that. i hope you have gotten the info you need. you asked so earnestly how to read i figured i would tell you the first steps. but you have followed all the steps so far, so i guess i have to keep giving the next steps. basically i am trying to get the rhythms squared away before you start doing pitches. i mean it's a very organized system. after getting this far, you should be able to figure it out yourself. once you know what quarter notes and 8th notes are you can easily figure out how 16th notes work. the beaming and flagging rules get a little interesting once you start putting rests in interesting places. but let's try this: let's do offbeat 8th notes. so that means start with an 8th rest (looks like a weird 7, for no reason) then an 8th note. NOT beamed, but it will have a flag. if you just look up an image for an eight note you should see it. looks like a quarter note with a flag on top. so do 8th rest, 8th note. four times, and that should fill up the bar. so it sounds the same as a bar full of 8th notes, but every other one (alternating) will be missing. if you could link me to an imgur image or something i could easily confirm if you are doing it right. but otherwise i will have to just hope that you are doing it right. if you play this rhythm, with a metronome, the notes will be exactly in between the clicks. i hope that makes sense. please i would like to remind everyone that this is a multi part question that was started on 11.29.16 at 1:52pm, with the question "how to learn to read music?". If you are prompting me to go to the next step, and you are not the original person who posted that question at that time, you are being dishonest, and that is something you are going to have to live with

009143.question: I've drawn out the eighth rests/notes- is there any convention about where to position rests relative to the notes? here's an image of what I've done http://imgur.com/on9WYJ5 (also thank you for addressing the imitation stuff)
009143.answer: looks great. the note heads might not need to be so big and full, but that is something you will get the hang of as you continue writing. of all your rests the first one looks the best, but even that doesn't need to be as perfectly drawn as you have drawn it. if you start to write a lot of music you will find quicker ways of just zinging everything in. note heads usually turn into almost a slanted line. anyway, it looks great. the alignment is good. usually alignment should adhere basically to the timing, but in some cases you can stretch it a little for readability. for example if you have a bunch if 16th note crap on one side of the bar and nothing in the other side sometimes you may stretch the complicated side out a little bit. anyway, that looks great. 16th notes are just like 8th notes, but they use 2 flags instead of 1 (or a double beam instead of 1.) ok i think you are good with rhythms for now. i think the next step is to figure out the pitches. the next step might be different depending on what instrument you are most familiar with. if you are not familiar with the layout of notes on a piano, learning to read might be a total nightmare. i'm not sure. but try putting notes on every line and every space. the notes in your example are perfectly aligned in the space (that would be A in treble clef). when a note is on the line, it should be the same size, so the top and bottom of the head should reach about halfway thru the space on either side of the line. i would say, make a bunch of notes in a row, going up. just like you would write a series of quarter notes, but don't use any stems, and don't use any bar lines. ignore the time for now, just line them all up. kind of like an ascending staircase of notes. start anywhere (probably on the bottom line? or you can even start with one just below the bottom line if you want) and put the notes in, going up. line, space, line, space, etc. news flash this is the white keys on a piano. i will tell you which ones they are later. i hope this makes sense
