009214.question: I've made an ascending staircase of notes. luckily I have a keyboard so I'm familiar with the layout of notes (but I can't remember which key is which note unless I count from a C)

009215.question: and here's a pic of what I've drawn, just so you know it's me. I'm sending it separately so that people can't pretend to be me in the future, since they won't have the information to. https://imgur.com/a/uhEcC
009215.answer: ok great. so your example shows 11 notes. they are all white keys on the keyboard. but the keyboard goes way higher and lower than that, all the notes could never fit into this one staff. so we need to specify what range we are in. actually there are only 2 commonly used range settings for the staff (the settings are called 'clefs') the most commonly used ones are treble and bass. let's look at treble for now. to specify that your staff is being used as a treble cleff, you need to put a treble clef symbol at the far left side of the staff, before the music starts. the treble clef symbol is crazy. good luck learning to draw it, but when you do learn it is fun. i usually start from the bottom, and draw a straight line up and then curve around and down. i think that is the easiest way to draw it. ok, so make a treble clef symbol on the left, and then make another staircase of notes, except this time start one lower than you started before (but what? there is no line there?) well make a tiny piece of a line, just big enough to house the note. then put the second note where your first note was in the previous example. make a total of 8 notes. your first and last note will be C. this is a C major scale. the lower C (the one you had to make a special line for) is called middle C. on a guitar, it is the first fret on the B string. on a bass guitar it is the 17th fret on the g string. on a piano it is somewhere in the middle of the piano. the frequency is about 262hz. let me know if you have got the scale written

009224.question: i've been teaching myself how to play the piano for a while now, but the one thing i can't get down is playing with two hands at once (like have the 'background track' playing with one hand and the main tune with the other, if you get my meaning). any tips? thanks, love your stuff by the way.
009224.answer: i am actually not so keen on that either. to do that, you basically need 3 elements- bass, chords, and melody. that's 3 things, and you only have 2 hands. there are different strategies -- one is to play the bass with your left hand, and chords with your right hand, and sing the melody. another strategy is to play in a band where there is a bass player, your left hand plays chords, your right hand plays the melody (that would be like in a jazz trio or whatever). or maybe there is a bass player and a singer also, in which case you have both hands free to do the chords. the piano is used in many different contexts, and in many different ways. if you are trying to do an entire piece of music by yourself, i think it is better to do the melody and chords in the same hand (right hand) and play the bass with your left hand. so basically just harmonize the melody, and keep the melody note on top of each chord. because if you have chords in your left hand then there's no bass? so that would be awkward. here's the issue i have with the whole situation-- i think in most music, the melody is actually in the same range as the chords. so if you are doing chords and melody at the same time on the same instrument, they are really going to occupy the same space on the keyboard. that is why i prefer to keep them both in the same range. there are so many different ways to make music, you have to just experiment and do what is right for the situation, depending on whether or not you are singing, and/or if you are playing with other players

009228.question: luckily treble clefs used to be my favourite thing to doodle on school work. I've got the scale written. I could send a pic if you want but I'm pretty sure it's ok. what's next?
009228.answer: ok, let's figure out how to make the other notes (the black keys). you will need flat and sharp symbols. let's use E. make an E note (it doesn't matter what rhythm it is). To make it an Eb (E flat) put the flat symbol immediately to the left of the note, aligned on the same line or space as the note. the flat symbol looks kind of like a lower case b, make sure the bump on the b is aligned the same way as the note. so if your note is on the bottom line (E) the flat symbol should be aligned to the bottom line, and just to the left of a note. if you make a line of E's, then make an Eb, you can keep making Eb's without putting any more flat signs. the flat symbol stays in effect for that note until the end of the bar. (some people say it's until the end of the line? not really sure actually. let's assume it is effective until the end of the bar.) Let's make a string of 8th notes (beamed in groups of 4), and put a flat symbol next to the 3rd note. now put a NATURAL symbol ♮ next to the second to last note. the natural symbol is aligned according to the box in the middle. so put that box right on the same line (or space) as the note. the natural symbol is a way to undo the flat symbol. so if you have written this correctly, you should have 2 E notes, then 4 Eb notes, then the last 2 would be back to E (natural, which means not flat or sharp.) and you will have only used 1 flat sign and 1 natural sign. i hope this makes sense

009267.question: done the f notes- https://imgur.com/a/W96VD another question: f sharp and g flat are the same on the piano right? is there a reason you'd pick one over the other when writing?
009267.answer: yes they are the same. there are various reasons you might choose one over the other. when we get into key signatures you should see this a little more clearly. if you have d, e, f#, g, a, you always want to use f# there instead of Gb because that way you have one letter for each note (one note on each line or space). if you used Gb in that situation, you would have no Fs and 2 Gs and you would have to keep flatting and unflatting the G. the 5 notes i just mentioned are actually part of a D major scale. so when you are in D major, for example, you can actually put the sharp symbol on the F line, at the beginning of the chart, (and also on C#, for the key of D) and then you can just use all the notes normally from D to D, and it automatically makes a D major scale because you already specified that the F and C notes are always sharp. (that is called a key signature). if you tried to use Gb and Db to make a D major scale, you would have to constantly be flatting and naturaling the D and G. it would be a freakin mess. but with a key signature, you just flip the F and C to sharps at the very beginning, and then all the notes in your staff automatically make D major. then if you want to flip to D min for a moment, you can use a natural sign on the F to make it temporarily natural. let me know if this makes sense and then i can try to show you the key signatures in a logical order

009274.question: ok great that makes sense (played the scale on a keyboard and i get what you're saying). ready for the next step, thanks
009274.answer: ok let's make a melody and then put it in different keys. the melody is going to be 8 8th notes in the first bar, then 2 quarter notes and a half note in the second bar. a half note looks like a quarter note with a hollow head, and it rhythmically lasts for 2 beats, or half of the bar. the notes are going to be: c d e g f e d c b, d, c. Start on middle C, which is that one off the bottom that needed a special piece of a line (that's called a ledger line by the way). there are no big jumps in this melody, so assume that each note is the one nearest to the previous (not an octave away). the highest note would be g, the lowest note is B, which is actually below the ledger line! so you have to make a ledger line just like you did for C, but put B below it. you don't need to make a ledger line for D. so this tune should have a total of 4 ledger lines. again, a ledger line is that little piece of a line that you made for C when it was off the edge of the staff. ok so that's the melody. try to sing or play it if you can. then we are going to move it into different keys and see which flats or sharps we need to use

009336.question: okay I've done that step. my bar spacing looks a bit weird though- https://imgur.com/a/InxMS also I find it quite hard to play the notes (keyboard) whilst reading but I imagine that's something I just need to practice a fuckton
009336.answer: i keep getting the feeling that you already know all this stuff, because you are doing everything perfectly, including things i haven't said yet (like the time signature). ok so take a look at the keyboard. play a C major scale (that's all the white keys from C up to C.) you will notice that all the notes are NOT actually the same distance apart, sound wise. to prove this, start on B and play all the white notes from B to B, it does NOT sound like a B major scale. to actually play every note you would include the black notes too. when you just play the white notes, you are getting a combination of larger and smaller intervals (called a 'whole step' or 'half step') depending on whether there is a black note in between. if you play all the notes going up, including white and black, you would get ALL half steps. i'm sure you already know all this. But let's look at the keyboard again, and look at the pattern of white/black keys, near the C note. you will notice that there is Another place on the keyboard where this pattern is almost the same, and that is near F. in other words, the black/white key configuration surrounding F is very similar to the black/white key configuration surrounding C. so start playing a scale starting from F, and play all the white notes from F to F. you may notice that this sounds Almost like an F major scale, but one note is wrong. the B. you can clearly see that that is where the black/white key pattern is not the same as it would have been for C. in C, going from the 3rd to 4th note there is no black note in between. but in F, there IS a black note there. in order to play a major scale right, that 3 to 4 interval needs to be a half step, just like it is in C. so when we play in F, you need to use the Bb note INSTEAD of B. play Bb, skip B. so play F, G, A, Bb, C, D, E, F. and that should sound like the F major scale. as long as all the B's are always flat, you are safely in F major. when we write, this is where you use a 'key signature'. put a flat sign on the middle line. this goes right after the treble clef symbol, and before the time signature. this one flat will apply to every B in the tune, including the higher and lower ones! that's just the way it works. but don't put the key signature on the one you wrote in C! that would mess it up. start a new one, put the flat on the B line (again that is the F key signature), and write the melody again, starting on F! you almost don't even have to know the notes, just follow the same pattern through the scale. up 1, up 1, up 2, down 1, etc. when the melody moves up one, it goes from a line to a space (or space to a line). when it goes up 2, it goes from space to space, or line to line. these are the patterns you are looking for when you read and write, and as long as you get your key signature right, it should be pretty easy. let me know if you need me to name the notes, but i would guess that you have this whole thing figured out by now.

009957.question: My piano teacher says that music without voice is a piece, and music with a voice is a song. Should I listen to them, or are they just being pedantic?
009957.answer: 'piece' is usually when talking about classical music. other types of instrumental music might be called different things. for a video game, it might be called a 'track.' if it's in a movie, it might be called the 'score.' if it is at a construction site it might be called a 'jackhammer'. but it is important to remember that you can call anything anything. in england they call the door the tv or something, and in america they measure everything with their hands and feet. it's good to be flexible, and creative, with language. it will all change in 100 years anyway
